1799         assert_(low < x.min() < x.max() < high)
1800 
1801         low, high = -10001, -10000
1802         x = stats.truncnorm.rvs(low, high, 0, 1, size=10)
1803         assert_(low < x.min() < x.max() < high)
1804 
1805     def test_gh_9403_nontail_values(self):
1806         for low, high in [[3, 4], [-4, -3]]:
1807             xvals = np.array([-np.inf, low, high, np.inf])
1808             xmid = (high+low)/2.0
1809             cdfs = stats.truncnorm.cdf(xvals, low, high)
1810             sfs = stats.truncnorm.sf(xvals, low, high)
1811             pdfs = stats.truncnorm.pdf(xvals, low, high)
1812             expected_cdfs = np.array([0, 0, 1, 1])
1813             expected_sfs = np.array([1.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0])
1814             expected_pdfs = np.array([0, 3.3619772, 0.1015229, 0])
1815             if low < 0:
1816                 expected_pdfs = np.array([0, 0.1015229, 3.3619772, 0])
1817             assert_almost_equal(cdfs, expected_cdfs)
1818             assert_almost_equal(sfs, expected_sfs)
1819             assert_almost_equal(pdfs, expected_pdfs)
1820             assert_almost_equal(np.log(expected_pdfs[1]/expected_pdfs[2]),
1821                                 low + 0.5)
1822             pvals = np.array([0, 0.5, 1.0])
1823             ppfs = stats.truncnorm.ppf(pvals, low, high)
1824             expected_ppfs = np.array([low, np.sign(low)*3.1984741, high])
1825             assert_almost_equal(ppfs, expected_ppfs)
1826 
1827             if low < 0:
1828                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.sf(xmid, low, high),
1829                                     0.8475544278436675)
1830                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.cdf(xmid, low, high),
1831                                     0.1524455721563326)
1832             else:
1833                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.cdf(xmid, low, high),
1834                                     0.8475544278436675)
1835                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.sf(xmid, low, high),
1836                                     0.1524455721563326)
1837             pdf = stats.truncnorm.pdf(xmid, low, high)
1838             assert_almost_equal(np.log(pdf/expected_pdfs[2]), (xmid+0.25)/2)
1839 
1840     def test_gh_9403_medium_tail_values(self):
1841         for low, high in [[39, 40], [-40, -39]]:
1842             xvals = np.array([-np.inf, low, high, np.inf])
1843             xmid = (high+low)/2.0
1844             cdfs = stats.truncnorm.cdf(xvals, low, high)
1845             sfs = stats.truncnorm.sf(xvals, low, high)
1846             pdfs = stats.truncnorm.pdf(xvals, low, high)
1847             expected_cdfs = np.array([0, 0, 1, 1])
1848             expected_sfs = np.array([1.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0])
1849             expected_pdfs = np.array([0, 3.90256074e+01, 2.73349092e-16, 0])
1850             if low < 0:
1851                 expected_pdfs = np.array([0, 2.73349092e-16,
1852                                           3.90256074e+01, 0])
1853             assert_almost_equal(cdfs, expected_cdfs)
1854             assert_almost_equal(sfs, expected_sfs)
1855             assert_almost_equal(pdfs, expected_pdfs)
1856             assert_almost_equal(np.log(expected_pdfs[1]/expected_pdfs[2]),
1857                                 low + 0.5)
1858             pvals = np.array([0, 0.5, 1.0])
1859             ppfs = stats.truncnorm.ppf(pvals, low, high)
1860             expected_ppfs = np.array([low, np.sign(low)*39.01775731, high])
1861             assert_almost_equal(ppfs, expected_ppfs)
1862             cdfs = stats.truncnorm.cdf(ppfs, low, high)
1863             assert_almost_equal(cdfs, pvals)
1864 
1865             if low < 0:
1866                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.sf(xmid, low, high),
1867                                     0.9999999970389126)
1868                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.cdf(xmid, low, high),
1869                                     2.961048103554866e-09)
1870             else:
1871                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.cdf(xmid, low, high),
1872                                     0.9999999970389126)
1873                 assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.sf(xmid, low, high),
1874                                     2.961048103554866e-09)
1875             pdf = stats.truncnorm.pdf(xmid, low, high)
1876             assert_almost_equal(np.log(pdf/expected_pdfs[2]), (xmid+0.25)/2)
1877 
1878             xvals = np.linspace(low, high, 11)
1879             xvals2 = -xvals[::-1]
1880             assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.cdf(xvals, low, high),
1881                                 stats.truncnorm.sf(xvals2, -high, -low)[::-1])
1882             assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.sf(xvals, low, high),
1883                                 stats.truncnorm.cdf(xvals2, -high, -low)[::-1])
1884             assert_almost_equal(stats.truncnorm.pdf(xvals, low, high),
1885                                 stats.truncnorm.pdf(xvals2, -high, -low)[::-1])
1886 
1887     def test_cdf_tail_15110_14753(self):
1888         # Check accuracy issues reported in gh-14753 and gh-155110
1889         # Ground truth values calculated using Wolfram Alpha, e.g.
1890         # (CDF[NormalDistribution[0,1],83/10]-CDF[NormalDistribution[0,1],8])/
1891         #     (1 - CDF[NormalDistribution[0,1],8])
1892         assert_allclose(stats.truncnorm(13., 15.).cdf(14.),
1893                         0.9999987259565643)
1894         assert_allclose(stats.truncnorm(8, np.inf).cdf(8.3),
1895                         0.9163220907327540)
1896 
1897     # Test data for the truncnorm stats() method.
1898     # The data in each row is:
1899     #   a, b, mean, variance, skewness, excess kurtosis. Generated using
1900     # https://gist.github.com/WarrenWeckesser/636b537ee889679227d53543d333a720
1901     _truncnorm_stats_data = [
1902         [-30, 30,
1903          0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0],
1904         [-10, 10,
1905          0.0, 1.0, 0.0, -1.4927521335810455e-19],
1906         [-3, 3,
1907          0.0, 0.9733369246625415, 0.0, -0.17111443639774404],
1908         [-2, 2,
1909          0.0, 0.7737413035499232, 0.0, -0.6344632828703505],
1910         [0, np.inf,
1911          0.7978845608028654,
1912          0.3633802276324187,
1913          0.995271746431156,
1914          0.8691773036059741],
1915         [-np.inf, 0,
1916          -0.7978845608028654,
1917          0.3633802276324187,
1918          -0.995271746431156,
1919          0.8691773036059741],
1920         [-1, 3,
1921          0.282786110727154,
1922          0.6161417353578293,
1923          0.5393018494027877,
1924          -0.20582065135274694],
1925         [-3, 1,
1926          -0.282786110727154,
1927          0.6161417353578293,
1928          -0.5393018494027877,
1929          -0.20582065135274694],
1930         [-10, -9,
1931          -9.108456288012409,
1932          0.011448805821636248,
1933          -1.8985607290949496,
1934          5.0733461105025075],
1935     ]
1936     _truncnorm_stats_data = np.array(_truncnorm_stats_data)
1937 
1938     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case", _truncnorm_stats_data)
1939     def test_moments(self, case):
1940         a, b, m0, v0, s0, k0 = case
1941         m, v, s, k = stats.truncnorm.stats(a, b, moments='mvsk')
1942         assert_allclose([m, v, s, k], [m0, v0, s0, k0], atol=1e-17)
1943 
1944     def test_9902_moments(self):
1945         m, v = stats.truncnorm.stats(0, np.inf, moments='mv')
1946         assert_almost_equal(m, 0.79788456)
1947         assert_almost_equal(v, 0.36338023)
1948 
1949     def test_gh_1489_trac_962_rvs(self):
1950         # Check the original example.
1951         low, high = 10, 15
1952         x = stats.truncnorm.rvs(low, high, 0, 1, size=10)
1953         assert_(low < x.min() < x.max() < high)
1954 
1955     def test_gh_11299_rvs(self):
1956         # Arose from investigating gh-11299
1957         # Test multiple shape parameters simultaneously.
1958         low = [-10, 10, -np.inf, -5, -np.inf, -np.inf, -45, -45, 40, -10, 40]
1959         high = [-5, 11, 5, np.inf, 40, -40, 40, -40, 45, np.inf, np.inf]
1960         x = stats.truncnorm.rvs(low, high, size=(5, len(low)))
1961         assert np.shape(x) == (5, len(low))
1962         assert_(np.all(low <= x.min(axis=0)))
1963         assert_(np.all(x.max(axis=0) <= high))
1964 
1965     def test_rvs_Generator(self):
1966         # check that rvs can use a Generator
1967         if hasattr(np.random, "default_rng"):
1968             stats.truncnorm.rvs(-10, -5, size=5,
1969                                 random_state=np.random.default_rng())
1970 
1971     def test_logcdf_gh17064(self):
1972         # regression test for gh-17064 - avoid roundoff error for logcdfs ~0
1973         a = np.array([-np.inf, -np.inf, -8, -np.inf, 10])
1974         b = np.array([np.inf, np.inf, 8, 10, np.inf])
1975         x = np.array([10, 7.5, 7.5, 9, 20])
1976         expected = [-7.619853024160525e-24, -3.190891672910947e-14,
1977                     -3.128682067168231e-14, -1.1285122074235991e-19,
1978                     -3.61374964828753e-66]
1979         assert_allclose(stats.truncnorm(a, b).logcdf(x), expected)
1980         assert_allclose(stats.truncnorm(-b, -a).logsf(-x), expected)
1981 
1982     def test_moments_gh18634(self):
1983         # gh-18634 reported that moments 5 and higher didn't work; check that
1984         # this is resolved
1985         res = stats.truncnorm(-2, 3).moment(5)
1986         # From Mathematica:
1987         # Moment[TruncatedDistribution[{-2, 3}, NormalDistribution[]], 5]
1988         ref = 1.645309620208361
1989         assert_allclose(res, ref)
1990 
1991 
1992 class TestGenLogistic:
1993 
1994     # Expected values computed with mpmath with 50 digits of precision.
1995     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, expected', [(-1000, -1499.5945348918917),
1996                                              (-125, -187.09453489189184),
1997                                              (0, -1.3274028432916989),
1998                                              (100, -99.59453489189184),
1999                                              (1000, -999.5945348918918)])
2000     def test_logpdf(self, x, expected):
2001         c = 1.5
2002         logp = stats.genlogistic.logpdf(x, c)
2003         assert_allclose(logp, expected, rtol=1e-13)
2004 
2005     # Expected values computed with mpmath with 50 digits of precision
2006     # from mpmath import mp
2007     # mp.dps = 50
2008     # def entropy_mp(c):
2009     #     c = mp.mpf(c)
2010     #     return float(-mp.log(c)+mp.one+mp.digamma(c + mp.one) + mp.euler)
2011 
2012     @pytest.mark.parametrize('c, ref', [(1e-100, 231.25850929940458),
2013                                         (1e-4, 10.21050485336338),
2014                                         (1e8, 1.577215669901533),
2015                                         (1e100, 1.5772156649015328)])
2016     def test_entropy(self, c, ref):
2017         assert_allclose(stats.genlogistic.entropy(c), ref, rtol=5e-15)
2018 
2019     # Expected values computed with mpmath with 50 digits of precision
2020     # from mpmath import mp
2021     # mp.dps = 1000
2022     #
2023     # def genlogistic_cdf_mp(x, c):
2024     #     x = mp.mpf(x)
2025     #     c = mp.mpf(c)
2026     #     return (mp.one + mp.exp(-x)) ** (-c)
2027     #
2028     # def genlogistic_sf_mp(x, c):
2029     #     return mp.one - genlogistic_cdf_mp(x, c)
2030     #
2031     # x, c, ref = 100, 0.02, -7.440151952041672e-466
2032     # print(float(mp.log(genlogistic_cdf_mp(x, c))))
2033     # ppf/isf reference values generated by passing in `ref` (`q` is produced)
2034 
2035     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, c, ref', [(200, 10, 1.3838965267367375e-86),
2036                                            (500, 20, 1.424915281348257e-216)])
2037     def test_sf(self, x, c, ref):
2038         assert_allclose(stats.genlogistic.sf(x, c), ref, rtol=1e-14)
2039 
2040     @pytest.mark.parametrize('q, c, ref', [(0.01, 200, 9.898441467379765),
2041                                            (0.001, 2, 7.600152115573173)])
2042     def test_isf(self, q, c, ref):
2043         assert_allclose(stats.genlogistic.isf(q, c), ref, rtol=5e-16)
2044 
2045     @pytest.mark.parametrize('q, c, ref', [(0.5, 200, 5.6630969187064615),
2046                                            (0.99, 20, 7.595630231412436)])
2047     def test_ppf(self, q, c, ref):
2048         assert_allclose(stats.genlogistic.ppf(q, c), ref, rtol=5e-16)
2049 
2050     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, c, ref', [(100, 0.02, -7.440151952041672e-46),
2051                                            (50, 20, -3.857499695927835e-21)])
2052     def test_logcdf(self, x, c, ref):
2053         assert_allclose(stats.genlogistic.logcdf(x, c), ref, rtol=1e-15)
2054 
2055 
2056 class TestHypergeom:
2057     def setup_method(self):
2058         np.random.seed(1234)
2059 
2060     def test_rvs(self):
2061         vals = stats.hypergeom.rvs(20, 10, 3, size=(2, 50))
2062         assert np.all(vals >= 0) & np.all(vals <= 3)
2063         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
2064         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2065         val = stats.hypergeom.rvs(20, 3, 10)
2066         assert isinstance(val, int)
2067         val = stats.hypergeom(20, 3, 10).rvs(3)
2068         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
2069         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2070 
2071     def test_precision(self):
2072         # comparison number from mpmath
2073         M = 2500
2074         n = 50
2075         N = 500
2076         tot = M
2077         good = n
2078         hgpmf = stats.hypergeom.pmf(2, tot, good, N)
2079         assert_almost_equal(hgpmf, 0.0010114963068932233, 11)
2080 
2081     def test_args(self):
2082         # test correct output for corner cases of arguments
2083         # see gh-2325
2084         assert_almost_equal(stats.hypergeom.pmf(0, 2, 1, 0), 1.0, 11)
2085         assert_almost_equal(stats.hypergeom.pmf(1, 2, 1, 0), 0.0, 11)
2086 
2087         assert_almost_equal(stats.hypergeom.pmf(0, 2, 0, 2), 1.0, 11)
2088         assert_almost_equal(stats.hypergeom.pmf(1, 2, 1, 0), 0.0, 11)
2089 
2090     def test_cdf_above_one(self):
2091         # for some values of parameters, hypergeom cdf was >1, see gh-2238
2092         assert_(0 <= stats.hypergeom.cdf(30, 13397950, 4363, 12390) <= 1.0)
2093 
2094     def test_precision2(self):
2095         # Test hypergeom precision for large numbers.  See #1218.
2096         # Results compared with those from R.
2097         oranges = 9.9e4
2098         pears = 1.1e5
2099         fruits_eaten = np.array([3, 3.8, 3.9, 4, 4.1, 4.2, 5]) * 1e4
2100         quantile = 2e4
2101         res = [stats.hypergeom.sf(quantile, oranges + pears, oranges, eaten)
2102                for eaten in fruits_eaten]
2103         expected = np.array([0, 1.904153e-114, 2.752693e-66, 4.931217e-32,
2104                              8.265601e-11, 0.1237904, 1])
2105         assert_allclose(res, expected, atol=0, rtol=5e-7)
2106 
2107         # Test with array_like first argument
2108         quantiles = [1.9e4, 2e4, 2.1e4, 2.15e4]
2109         res2 = stats.hypergeom.sf(quantiles, oranges + pears, oranges, 4.2e4)
2110         expected2 = [1, 0.1237904, 6.511452e-34, 3.277667e-69]
2111         assert_allclose(res2, expected2, atol=0, rtol=5e-7)
2112 
2113     def test_entropy(self):
2114         # Simple tests of entropy.
2115         hg = stats.hypergeom(4, 1, 1)
2116         h = hg.entropy()
2117         expected_p = np.array([0.75, 0.25])
2118         expected_h = -np.sum(xlogy(expected_p, expected_p))
2119         assert_allclose(h, expected_h)
2120 
2121         hg = stats.hypergeom(1, 1, 1)
2122         h = hg.entropy()
2123         assert_equal(h, 0.0)
2124 
2125     def test_logsf(self):
2126         # Test logsf for very large numbers. See issue #4982
2127         # Results compare with those from R (v3.2.0):
2128         # phyper(k, n, M-n, N, lower.tail=FALSE, log.p=TRUE)
2129         # -2239.771
2130 
2131         k = 1e4
2132         M = 1e7
2133         n = 1e6
2134         N = 5e4
2135 
2136         result = stats.hypergeom.logsf(k, M, n, N)
2137         expected = -2239.771   # From R
2138         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=3)
2139 
2140         k = 1
2141         M = 1600
2142         n = 600
2143         N = 300
2144 
2145         result = stats.hypergeom.logsf(k, M, n, N)
2146         expected = -2.566567e-68   # From R
2147         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=15)
2148 
2149     def test_logcdf(self):
2150         # Test logcdf for very large numbers. See issue #8692
2151         # Results compare with those from R (v3.3.2):
2152         # phyper(k, n, M-n, N, lower.tail=TRUE, log.p=TRUE)
2153         # -5273.335
2154 
2155         k = 1
2156         M = 1e7
2157         n = 1e6
2158         N = 5e4
2159 
2160         result = stats.hypergeom.logcdf(k, M, n, N)
2161         expected = -5273.335   # From R
2162         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=3)
2163 
2164         # Same example as in issue #8692
2165         k = 40
2166         M = 1600
2167         n = 50
2168         N = 300
2169 
2170         result = stats.hypergeom.logcdf(k, M, n, N)
2171         expected = -7.565148879229e-23    # From R
2172         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=15)
2173 
2174         k = 125
2175         M = 1600
2176         n = 250
2177         N = 500
2178 
2179         result = stats.hypergeom.logcdf(k, M, n, N)
2180         expected = -4.242688e-12    # From R
2181         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=15)
2182 
2183         # test broadcasting robustness based on reviewer
2184         # concerns in PR 9603; using an array version of
2185         # the example from issue #8692
2186         k = np.array([40, 40, 40])
2187         M = 1600
2188         n = 50
2189         N = 300
2190 
2191         result = stats.hypergeom.logcdf(k, M, n, N)
2192         expected = np.full(3, -7.565148879229e-23)  # filled from R result
2193         assert_almost_equal(result, expected, decimal=15)
2194 
2195     def test_mean_gh18511(self):
2196         # gh-18511 reported that the `mean` was incorrect for large arguments;
2197         # check that this is resolved
2198         M = 390_000
2199         n = 370_000
2200         N = 12_000
2201 
2202         hm = stats.hypergeom.mean(M, n, N)
2203         rm = n / M * N
2204         assert_allclose(hm, rm)
2205 
2206     @pytest.mark.xslow
2207     def test_sf_gh18506(self):
2208         # gh-18506 reported that `sf` was incorrect for large population;
2209         # check that this is resolved
2210         n = 10
2211         N = 10**5
2212         i = np.arange(5, 15)
2213         population_size = 10.**i
2214         p = stats.hypergeom.sf(n - 1, population_size, N, n)
2215         assert np.all(p > 0)
2216         assert np.all(np.diff(p) < 0)
2217 
2218 
2219 class TestLoggamma:
2220 
2221     # Expected cdf values were computed with mpmath. For given x and c,
2222     #     x = mpmath.mpf(x)
2223     #     c = mpmath.mpf(c)
2224     #     cdf = mpmath.gammainc(c, 0, mpmath.exp(x),
2225     #                           regularized=True)
2226     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, c, cdf',
2227                              [(1, 2, 0.7546378854206702),
2228                               (-1, 14, 6.768116452566383e-18),
2229                               (-745.1, 0.001, 0.4749605142005238),
2230                               (-800, 0.001, 0.44958802911019136),
2231                               (-725, 0.1, 3.4301205868273265e-32),
2232                               (-740, 0.75, 1.0074360436599631e-241)])
2233     def test_cdf_ppf(self, x, c, cdf):
2234         p = stats.loggamma.cdf(x, c)
2235         assert_allclose(p, cdf, rtol=1e-13)
2236         y = stats.loggamma.ppf(cdf, c)
2237         assert_allclose(y, x, rtol=1e-13)
2238 
2239     # Expected sf values were computed with mpmath. For given x and c,
2240     #     x = mpmath.mpf(x)
2241     #     c = mpmath.mpf(c)
2242     #     sf = mpmath.gammainc(c, mpmath.exp(x), mpmath.inf,
2243     #                          regularized=True)
2244     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, c, sf',
2245                              [(4, 1.5, 1.6341528919488565e-23),
2246                               (6, 100, 8.23836829202024e-74),
2247                               (-800, 0.001, 0.5504119708898086),
2248                               (-743, 0.0025, 0.8437131370024089)])
2249     def test_sf_isf(self, x, c, sf):
2250         s = stats.loggamma.sf(x, c)
2251         assert_allclose(s, sf, rtol=1e-13)
2252         y = stats.loggamma.isf(sf, c)
2253         assert_allclose(y, x, rtol=1e-13)
2254 
2255     def test_logpdf(self):
2256         # Test logpdf with x=-500, c=2.  ln(gamma(2)) = 0, and
2257         # exp(-500) ~= 7e-218, which is far smaller than the ULP
2258         # of c*x=-1000, so logpdf(-500, 2) = c*x - exp(x) - ln(gamma(2))
2259         # should give -1000.0.
2260         lp = stats.loggamma.logpdf(-500, 2)
2261         assert_allclose(lp, -1000.0, rtol=1e-14)
2262 
2263     def test_logcdf(self):
2264         x = 4.0
2265         c = 4.5
2266         logcdf = stats.loggamma.logcdf(x, c)
2267         # Reference value computed with mpmath.
2268         ref = -2.1429747073164531e-19
2269         assert_allclose(logcdf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
2270 
2271     def test_logsf(self):
2272         x = -25.0
2273         c = 3.5
2274         logsf = stats.loggamma.logsf(x, c)
2275         # Reference value computed with mpmath.
2276         ref = -8.58200139319556e-40
2277         assert_allclose(logsf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
2278 
2279     def test_stats(self):
2280         # The following precomputed values are from the table in section 2.2
2281         # of "A Statistical Study of Log-Gamma Distribution", by Ping Shing
2282         # Chan (thesis, McMaster University, 1993).
2283         table = np.array([
2284                 # c,    mean,   var,    skew,    exc. kurt.
2285                 0.5, -1.9635, 4.9348, -1.5351, 4.0000,
2286                 1.0, -0.5772, 1.6449, -1.1395, 2.4000,
2287                 12.0, 2.4427, 0.0869, -0.2946, 0.1735,
2288             ]).reshape(-1, 5)
2289         for c, mean, var, skew, kurt in table:
2290             computed = stats.loggamma.stats(c, moments='msvk')
2291             assert_array_almost_equal(computed, [mean, var, skew, kurt],
2292                                       decimal=4)
2293 
2294     @pytest.mark.parametrize('c', [0.1, 0.001])
2295     def test_rvs(self, c):
2296         # Regression test for gh-11094.
2297         x = stats.loggamma.rvs(c, size=100000)
2298         # Before gh-11094 was fixed, the case with c=0.001 would
2299         # generate many -inf values.
2300         assert np.isfinite(x).all()
2301         # Crude statistical test.  About half the values should be
2302         # less than the median and half greater than the median.
2303         med = stats.loggamma.median(c)
2304         btest = stats.binomtest(np.count_nonzero(x < med), len(x))
2305         ci = btest.proportion_ci(confidence_level=0.999)
2306         assert ci.low < 0.5 < ci.high
2307 
2308     @pytest.mark.parametrize("c, ref",
2309                              [(1e-8, 19.420680753952364),
2310                               (1, 1.5772156649015328),
2311                               (1e4, -3.186214986116763),
2312                               (1e10, -10.093986931748889),
2313                               (1e100, -113.71031611649761)])
2314     def test_entropy(self, c, ref):
2315 
2316         # Reference values were calculated with mpmath
2317         # from mpmath import mp
2318         # mp.dps = 500
2319         # def loggamma_entropy_mpmath(c):
2320         #     c = mp.mpf(c)
2321         #     return float(mp.log(mp.gamma(c)) + c * (mp.one - mp.digamma(c)))
2322 
2323         assert_allclose(stats.loggamma.entropy(c), ref, rtol=1e-14)
2324 
2325 
2326 class TestJohnsonsu:
2327     # reference values were computed via mpmath
2328     # from mpmath import mp
2329     # mp.dps = 50
2330     # def johnsonsu_sf(x, a, b):
2331     #     x = mp.mpf(x)
2332     #     a = mp.mpf(a)
2333     #     b = mp.mpf(b)
2334     #     return float(mp.ncdf(-(a + b * mp.log(x + mp.sqrt(x*x + 1)))))
2335     # Order is x, a, b, sf, isf tol
2336     # (Can't expect full precision when the ISF input is very nearly 1)
2337     cases = [(-500, 1, 1, 0.9999999982660072, 1e-8),
2338              (2000, 1, 1, 7.426351000595343e-21, 5e-14),
2339              (100000, 1, 1, 4.046923979269977e-40, 5e-14)]
2340 
2341     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case", cases)
2342     def test_sf_isf(self, case):
2343         x, a, b, sf, tol = case
2344         assert_allclose(stats.johnsonsu.sf(x, a, b), sf, rtol=5e-14)
2345         assert_allclose(stats.johnsonsu.isf(sf, a, b), x, rtol=tol)
2346 
2347 
2348 class TestJohnsonb:
2349     # reference values were computed via mpmath
2350     # from mpmath import mp
2351     # mp.dps = 50
2352     # def johnsonb_sf(x, a, b):
2353     #     x = mp.mpf(x)
2354     #     a = mp.mpf(a)
2355     #     b = mp.mpf(b)
2356     #     return float(mp.ncdf(-(a + b * mp.log(x/(mp.one - x)))))
2357     # Order is x, a, b, sf, isf atol
2358     # (Can't expect full precision when the ISF input is very nearly 1)
2359     cases = [(1e-4, 1, 1, 0.9999999999999999, 1e-7),
2360              (0.9999, 1, 1, 8.921114313932308e-25, 5e-14),
2361              (0.999999, 1, 1, 5.815197487181902e-50, 5e-14)]
2362 
2363     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case", cases)
2364     def test_sf_isf(self, case):
2365         x, a, b, sf, tol = case
2366         assert_allclose(stats.johnsonsb.sf(x, a, b), sf, rtol=5e-14)
2367         assert_allclose(stats.johnsonsb.isf(sf, a, b), x, atol=tol)
2368 
2369 
2370 class TestLogistic:
2371     # gh-6226
2372     def test_cdf_ppf(self):
2373         x = np.linspace(-20, 20)
2374         y = stats.logistic.cdf(x)
2375         xx = stats.logistic.ppf(y)
2376         assert_allclose(x, xx)
2377 
2378     def test_sf_isf(self):
2379         x = np.linspace(-20, 20)
2380         y = stats.logistic.sf(x)
2381         xx = stats.logistic.isf(y)
2382         assert_allclose(x, xx)
2383 
2384     def test_extreme_values(self):
2385         # p is chosen so that 1 - (1 - p) == p in double precision
2386         p = 9.992007221626409e-16
2387         desired = 34.53957599234088
2388         assert_allclose(stats.logistic.ppf(1 - p), desired)
2389         assert_allclose(stats.logistic.isf(p), desired)
2390 
2391     def test_logpdf_basic(self):
2392         logp = stats.logistic.logpdf([-15, 0, 10])
2393         # Expected values computed with mpmath with 50 digits of precision.
2394         expected = [-15.000000611804547,
2395                     -1.3862943611198906,
2396                     -10.000090797798434]
2397         assert_allclose(logp, expected, rtol=1e-13)
2398 
2399     def test_logpdf_extreme_values(self):
2400         logp = stats.logistic.logpdf([800, -800])
2401         # For such large arguments, logpdf(x) = -abs(x) when computed
2402         # with 64 bit floating point.
2403         assert_equal(logp, [-800, -800])
2404 
2405     @pytest.mark.parametrize("loc_rvs,scale_rvs", [(0.4484955, 0.10216821),
2406                                                    (0.62918191, 0.74367064)])
2407     def test_fit(self, loc_rvs, scale_rvs):
2408         data = stats.logistic.rvs(size=100, loc=loc_rvs, scale=scale_rvs)
2409 
2410         # test that result of fit method is the same as optimization
2411         def func(input, data):
2412             a, b = input
2413             n = len(data)
2414             x1 = np.sum(np.exp((data - a) / b) /
2415                         (1 + np.exp((data - a) / b))) - n / 2
2416             x2 = np.sum(((data - a) / b) *
2417                         ((np.exp((data - a) / b) - 1) /
2418                          (np.exp((data - a) / b) + 1))) - n
2419             return x1, x2
2420 
2421         expected_solution = root(func, stats.logistic._fitstart(data), args=(
2422             data,)).x
2423         fit_method = stats.logistic.fit(data)
2424 
2425         # other than computational variances, the fit method and the solution
2426         # to this system of equations are equal
2427         assert_allclose(fit_method, expected_solution, atol=1e-30)
2428 
2429     def test_fit_comp_optimizer(self):
2430         data = stats.logistic.rvs(size=100, loc=0.5, scale=2)
2431         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.logistic, data)
2432         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.logistic, data, floc=1)
2433         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.logistic, data, fscale=1)
2434 
2435     @pytest.mark.parametrize('testlogcdf', [True, False])
2436     def test_logcdfsf_tails(self, testlogcdf):
2437         # Test either logcdf or logsf.  By symmetry, we can use the same
2438         # expected values for both by switching the sign of x for logsf.
2439         x = np.array([-10000, -800, 17, 50, 500])
2440         if testlogcdf:
2441             y = stats.logistic.logcdf(x)
2442         else:
2443             y = stats.logistic.logsf(-x)
2444         # The expected values were computed with mpmath.
2445         expected = [-10000.0, -800.0, -4.139937633089748e-08,
2446                     -1.9287498479639178e-22, -7.124576406741286e-218]
2447         assert_allclose(y, expected, rtol=2e-15)
2448 
2449     def test_fit_gh_18176(self):
2450         # logistic.fit returned `scale < 0` for this data. Check that this has
2451         # been fixed.
2452         data = np.array([-459, 37, 43, 45, 45, 48, 54, 55, 58]
2453                         + [59] * 3 + [61] * 9)
2454         # If scale were negative, NLLF would be infinite, so this would fail
2455         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.logistic, data)
2456 
2457 
2458 class TestLogser:
2459     def setup_method(self):
2460         np.random.seed(1234)
2461 
2462     def test_rvs(self):
2463         vals = stats.logser.rvs(0.75, size=(2, 50))
2464         assert np.all(vals >= 1)
2465         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
2466         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2467         val = stats.logser.rvs(0.75)
2468         assert isinstance(val, int)
2469         val = stats.logser(0.75).rvs(3)
2470         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
2471         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2472 
2473     def test_pmf_small_p(self):
2474         m = stats.logser.pmf(4, 1e-20)
2475         # The expected value was computed using mpmath:
2476         #   >>> import mpmath
2477         #   >>> mpmath.mp.dps = 64
2478         #   >>> k = 4
2479         #   >>> p = mpmath.mpf('1e-20')
2480         #   >>> float(-(p**k)/k/mpmath.log(1-p))
2481         #   2.5e-61
2482         # It is also clear from noticing that for very small p,
2483         # log(1-p) is approximately -p, and the formula becomes
2484         #    p**(k-1) / k
2485         assert_allclose(m, 2.5e-61)
2486 
2487     def test_mean_small_p(self):
2488         m = stats.logser.mean(1e-8)
2489         # The expected mean was computed using mpmath:
2490         #   >>> import mpmath
2491         #   >>> mpmath.dps = 60
2492         #   >>> p = mpmath.mpf('1e-8')
2493         #   >>> float(-p / ((1 - p)*mpmath.log(1 - p)))
2494         #   1.000000005
2495         assert_allclose(m, 1.000000005)
2496 
2497 
2498 class TestGumbel_r_l:
2499     @pytest.fixture(scope='function')
2500     def rng(self):
2501         return np.random.default_rng(1234)
2502 
2503     @pytest.mark.parametrize("dist", [stats.gumbel_r, stats.gumbel_l])
2504     @pytest.mark.parametrize("loc_rvs", [-1, 0, 1])
2505     @pytest.mark.parametrize("scale_rvs", [.1, 1, 5])
2506     @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_loc, fix_scale',
2507                              ([True, False], [False, True]))
2508     def test_fit_comp_optimizer(self, dist, loc_rvs, scale_rvs,
2509                                 fix_loc, fix_scale, rng):
2510         data = dist.rvs(size=100, loc=loc_rvs, scale=scale_rvs,
2511                         random_state=rng)
2512 
2513         kwds = dict()
2514         # the fixed location and scales are arbitrarily modified to not be
2515         # close to the true value.
2516         if fix_loc:
2517             kwds['floc'] = loc_rvs * 2
2518         if fix_scale:
2519             kwds['fscale'] = scale_rvs * 2
2520 
2521         # test that the gumbel_* fit method is better than super method
2522         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(dist, data, **kwds)
2523 
2524     @pytest.mark.parametrize("dist, sgn", [(stats.gumbel_r, 1),
2525                                            (stats.gumbel_l, -1)])
2526     def test_fit(self, dist, sgn):
2527         z = sgn*np.array([3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3.00000001])
2528         loc, scale = dist.fit(z)
2529         # The expected values were computed with mpmath with 60 digits
2530         # of precision.
2531         assert_allclose(loc, sgn*3.0000000001667906)
2532         assert_allclose(scale, 1.2495222465145514e-09, rtol=1e-6)
2533 
2534 
2535 class TestPareto:
2536     def test_stats(self):
2537         # Check the stats() method with some simple values. Also check
2538         # that the calculations do not trigger RuntimeWarnings.
2539         with warnings.catch_warnings():
2540             warnings.simplefilter("error", RuntimeWarning)
2541 
2542             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(0.5, moments='mvsk')
2543             assert_equal(m, np.inf)
2544             assert_equal(v, np.inf)
2545             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2546             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2547 
2548             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(1.0, moments='mvsk')
2549             assert_equal(m, np.inf)
2550             assert_equal(v, np.inf)
2551             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2552             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2553 
2554             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(1.5, moments='mvsk')
2555             assert_equal(m, 3.0)
2556             assert_equal(v, np.inf)
2557             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2558             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2559 
2560             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(2.0, moments='mvsk')
2561             assert_equal(m, 2.0)
2562             assert_equal(v, np.inf)
2563             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2564             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2565 
2566             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(2.5, moments='mvsk')
2567             assert_allclose(m, 2.5 / 1.5)
2568             assert_allclose(v, 2.5 / (1.5*1.5*0.5))
2569             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2570             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2571 
2572             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(3.0, moments='mvsk')
2573             assert_allclose(m, 1.5)
2574             assert_allclose(v, 0.75)
2575             assert_equal(s, np.nan)
2576             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2577 
2578             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(3.5, moments='mvsk')
2579             assert_allclose(m, 3.5 / 2.5)
2580             assert_allclose(v, 3.5 / (2.5*2.5*1.5))
2581             assert_allclose(s, (2*4.5/0.5)*np.sqrt(1.5/3.5))
2582             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2583 
2584             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(4.0, moments='mvsk')
2585             assert_allclose(m, 4.0 / 3.0)
2586             assert_allclose(v, 4.0 / 18.0)
2587             assert_allclose(s, 2*(1+4.0)/(4.0-3) * np.sqrt((4.0-2)/4.0))
2588             assert_equal(k, np.nan)
2589 
2590             m, v, s, k = stats.pareto.stats(4.5, moments='mvsk')
2591             assert_allclose(m, 4.5 / 3.5)
2592             assert_allclose(v, 4.5 / (3.5*3.5*2.5))
2593             assert_allclose(s, (2*5.5/1.5) * np.sqrt(2.5/4.5))
2594             assert_allclose(k, 6*(4.5**3 + 4.5**2 - 6*4.5 - 2)/(4.5*1.5*0.5))
2595 
2596     def test_sf(self):
2597         x = 1e9
2598         b = 2
2599         scale = 1.5
2600         p = stats.pareto.sf(x, b, loc=0, scale=scale)
2601         expected = (scale/x)**b   # 2.25e-18
2602         assert_allclose(p, expected)
2603 
2604     @pytest.fixture(scope='function')
2605     def rng(self):
2606         return np.random.default_rng(1234)
2607 
2608     @pytest.mark.filterwarnings("ignore:invalid value encountered in "
2609                                 "double_scalars")
2610     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_shape", [1, 2])
2611     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc", [0, 2])
2612     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_scale", [1, 5])
2613     def test_fit(self, rvs_shape, rvs_loc, rvs_scale, rng):
2614         data = stats.pareto.rvs(size=100, b=rvs_shape, scale=rvs_scale,
2615                                 loc=rvs_loc, random_state=rng)
2616 
2617         # shape can still be fixed with multiple names
2618         shape_mle_analytical1 = stats.pareto.fit(data, floc=0, f0=1.04)[0]
2619         shape_mle_analytical2 = stats.pareto.fit(data, floc=0, fix_b=1.04)[0]
2620         shape_mle_analytical3 = stats.pareto.fit(data, floc=0, fb=1.04)[0]
2621         assert (shape_mle_analytical1 == shape_mle_analytical2 ==
2622                 shape_mle_analytical3 == 1.04)
2623 
2624         # data can be shifted with changes to `loc`
2625         data = stats.pareto.rvs(size=100, b=rvs_shape, scale=rvs_scale,
2626                                 loc=(rvs_loc + 2), random_state=rng)
2627         shape_mle_a, loc_mle_a, scale_mle_a = stats.pareto.fit(data, floc=2)
2628         assert_equal(scale_mle_a + 2, data.min())
2629 
2630         data_shift = data - 2
2631         ndata = data_shift.shape[0]
2632         assert_equal(shape_mle_a,
2633                      ndata / np.sum(np.log(data_shift/data_shift.min())))
2634         assert_equal(loc_mle_a, 2)
2635 
2636     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_shape", [.1, 2])
2637     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc", [0, 2])
2638     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_scale", [1, 5])
2639     @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_shape, fix_loc, fix_scale',
2640                              [p for p in product([True, False], repeat=3)
2641                               if False in p])
2642     @np.errstate(invalid="ignore")
2643     def test_fit_MLE_comp_optimizer(self, rvs_shape, rvs_loc, rvs_scale,
2644                                     fix_shape, fix_loc, fix_scale, rng):
2645         data = stats.pareto.rvs(size=100, b=rvs_shape, scale=rvs_scale,
2646                                 loc=rvs_loc, random_state=rng)
2647 
2648         kwds = {}
2649         if fix_shape:
2650             kwds['f0'] = rvs_shape
2651         if fix_loc:
2652             kwds['floc'] = rvs_loc
2653         if fix_scale:
2654             kwds['fscale'] = rvs_scale
2655 
2656         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.pareto, data, **kwds)
2657 
2658     @np.errstate(invalid="ignore")
2659     def test_fit_known_bad_seed(self):
2660         # Tests a known seed and set of parameters that would produce a result
2661         # would violate the support of Pareto if the fit method did not check
2662         # the constraint `fscale + floc < min(data)`.
2663         shape, location, scale = 1, 0, 1
2664         data = stats.pareto.rvs(shape, location, scale, size=100,
2665                                 random_state=np.random.default_rng(2535619))
2666         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.pareto, data)
2667 
2668     def test_fit_warnings(self):
2669         assert_fit_warnings(stats.pareto)
2670         # `floc` that causes invalid negative data
2671         assert_raises(FitDataError, stats.pareto.fit, [1, 2, 3], floc=2)
2672         # `floc` and `fscale` combination causes invalid data
2673         assert_raises(FitDataError, stats.pareto.fit, [5, 2, 3], floc=1,
2674                       fscale=3)
2675 
2676     def test_negative_data(self, rng):
2677         data = stats.pareto.rvs(loc=-130, b=1, size=100, random_state=rng)
2678         assert_array_less(data, 0)
2679         # The purpose of this test is to make sure that no runtime warnings are
2680         # raised for all negative data, not the output of the fit method. Other
2681         # methods test the output but have to silence warnings from the super
2682         # method.
2683         _ = stats.pareto.fit(data)
2684 
2685 
2686 class TestGenpareto:
2687     def test_ab(self):
2688         # c >= 0: a, b = [0, inf]
2689         for c in [1., 0.]:
2690             c = np.asarray(c)
2691             a, b = stats.genpareto._get_support(c)
2692             assert_equal(a, 0.)
2693             assert_(np.isposinf(b))
2694 
2695         # c < 0: a=0, b=1/|c|
2696         c = np.asarray(-2.)
2697         a, b = stats.genpareto._get_support(c)
2698         assert_allclose([a, b], [0., 0.5])
2699 
2700     def test_c0(self):
2701         # with c=0, genpareto reduces to the exponential distribution
2702         # rv = stats.genpareto(c=0.)
2703         rv = stats.genpareto(c=0.)
2704         x = np.linspace(0, 10., 30)
2705         assert_allclose(rv.pdf(x), stats.expon.pdf(x))
2706         assert_allclose(rv.cdf(x), stats.expon.cdf(x))
2707         assert_allclose(rv.sf(x), stats.expon.sf(x))
2708 
2709         q = np.linspace(0., 1., 10)
2710         assert_allclose(rv.ppf(q), stats.expon.ppf(q))
2711 
2712     def test_cm1(self):
2713         # with c=-1, genpareto reduces to the uniform distr on [0, 1]
2714         rv = stats.genpareto(c=-1.)
2715         x = np.linspace(0, 10., 30)
2716         assert_allclose(rv.pdf(x), stats.uniform.pdf(x))
2717         assert_allclose(rv.cdf(x), stats.uniform.cdf(x))
2718         assert_allclose(rv.sf(x), stats.uniform.sf(x))
2719 
2720         q = np.linspace(0., 1., 10)
2721         assert_allclose(rv.ppf(q), stats.uniform.ppf(q))
2722 
2723         # logpdf(1., c=-1) should be zero
2724         assert_allclose(rv.logpdf(1), 0)
2725 
2726     def test_x_inf(self):
2727         # make sure x=inf is handled gracefully
2728         rv = stats.genpareto(c=0.1)
2729         assert_allclose([rv.pdf(np.inf), rv.cdf(np.inf)], [0., 1.])
2730         assert_(np.isneginf(rv.logpdf(np.inf)))
2731 
2732         rv = stats.genpareto(c=0.)
2733         assert_allclose([rv.pdf(np.inf), rv.cdf(np.inf)], [0., 1.])
2734         assert_(np.isneginf(rv.logpdf(np.inf)))
2735 
2736         rv = stats.genpareto(c=-1.)
2737         assert_allclose([rv.pdf(np.inf), rv.cdf(np.inf)], [0., 1.])
2738         assert_(np.isneginf(rv.logpdf(np.inf)))
2739 
2740     def test_c_continuity(self):
2741         # pdf is continuous at c=0, -1
2742         x = np.linspace(0, 10, 30)
2743         for c in [0, -1]:
2744             pdf0 = stats.genpareto.pdf(x, c)
2745             for dc in [1e-14, -1e-14]:
2746                 pdfc = stats.genpareto.pdf(x, c + dc)
2747                 assert_allclose(pdf0, pdfc, atol=1e-12)
2748 
2749             cdf0 = stats.genpareto.cdf(x, c)
2750             for dc in [1e-14, 1e-14]:
2751                 cdfc = stats.genpareto.cdf(x, c + dc)
2752                 assert_allclose(cdf0, cdfc, atol=1e-12)
2753 
2754     def test_c_continuity_ppf(self):
2755         q = np.r_[np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1),
2756                   np.linspace(0.01, 1, 30, endpoint=False),
2757                   1. - np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1)]
2758         for c in [0., -1.]:
2759             ppf0 = stats.genpareto.ppf(q, c)
2760             for dc in [1e-14, -1e-14]:
2761                 ppfc = stats.genpareto.ppf(q, c + dc)
2762                 assert_allclose(ppf0, ppfc, atol=1e-12)
2763 
2764     def test_c_continuity_isf(self):
2765         q = np.r_[np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1),
2766                   np.linspace(0.01, 1, 30, endpoint=False),
2767                   1. - np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1)]
2768         for c in [0., -1.]:
2769             isf0 = stats.genpareto.isf(q, c)
2770             for dc in [1e-14, -1e-14]:
2771                 isfc = stats.genpareto.isf(q, c + dc)
2772                 assert_allclose(isf0, isfc, atol=1e-12)
2773 
2774     def test_cdf_ppf_roundtrip(self):
2775         # this should pass with machine precision. hat tip @pbrod
2776         q = np.r_[np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1),
2777                   np.linspace(0.01, 1, 30, endpoint=False),
2778                   1. - np.logspace(1e-12, 0.01, base=0.1)]
2779         for c in [1e-8, -1e-18, 1e-15, -1e-15]:
2780             assert_allclose(stats.genpareto.cdf(stats.genpareto.ppf(q, c), c),
2781                             q, atol=1e-15)
2782 
2783     def test_logsf(self):
2784         logp = stats.genpareto.logsf(1e10, .01, 0, 1)
2785         assert_allclose(logp, -1842.0680753952365)
2786 
2787     # Values in 'expected_stats' are
2788     # [mean, variance, skewness, excess kurtosis].
2789     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
2790         'c, expected_stats',
2791         [(0, [1, 1, 2, 6]),
2792          (1/4, [4/3, 32/9, 10/np.sqrt(2), np.nan]),
2793          (1/9, [9/8, (81/64)*(9/7), (10/9)*np.sqrt(7), 754/45]),
2794          (-1, [1/2, 1/12, 0, -6/5])])
2795     def test_stats(self, c, expected_stats):
2796         result = stats.genpareto.stats(c, moments='mvsk')
2797         assert_allclose(result, expected_stats, rtol=1e-13, atol=1e-15)
2798 
2799     def test_var(self):
2800         # Regression test for gh-11168.
2801         v = stats.genpareto.var(1e-8)
2802         assert_allclose(v, 1.000000040000001, rtol=1e-13)
2803 
2804 
2805 class TestPearson3:
2806     def setup_method(self):
2807         np.random.seed(1234)
2808 
2809     def test_rvs(self):
2810         vals = stats.pearson3.rvs(0.1, size=(2, 50))
2811         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
2812         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllFloat']
2813         val = stats.pearson3.rvs(0.5)
2814         assert isinstance(val, float)
2815         val = stats.pearson3(0.5).rvs(3)
2816         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
2817         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllFloat']
2818         assert len(val) == 3
2819 
2820     def test_pdf(self):
2821         vals = stats.pearson3.pdf(2, [0.0, 0.1, 0.2])
2822         assert_allclose(vals, np.array([0.05399097, 0.05555481, 0.05670246]),
2823                         atol=1e-6)
2824         vals = stats.pearson3.pdf(-3, 0.1)
2825         assert_allclose(vals, np.array([0.00313791]), atol=1e-6)
2826         vals = stats.pearson3.pdf([-3, -2, -1, 0, 1], 0.1)
2827         assert_allclose(vals, np.array([0.00313791, 0.05192304, 0.25028092,
2828                                         0.39885918, 0.23413173]), atol=1e-6)
2829 
2830     def test_cdf(self):
2831         vals = stats.pearson3.cdf(2, [0.0, 0.1, 0.2])
2832         assert_allclose(vals, np.array([0.97724987, 0.97462004, 0.97213626]),
2833                         atol=1e-6)
2834         vals = stats.pearson3.cdf(-3, 0.1)
2835         assert_allclose(vals, [0.00082256], atol=1e-6)
2836         vals = stats.pearson3.cdf([-3, -2, -1, 0, 1], 0.1)
2837         assert_allclose(vals, [8.22563821e-04, 1.99860448e-02, 1.58550710e-01,
2838                                5.06649130e-01, 8.41442111e-01], atol=1e-6)
2839 
2840     def test_negative_cdf_bug_11186(self):
2841         # incorrect CDFs for negative skews in gh-11186; fixed in gh-12640
2842         # Also check vectorization w/ negative, zero, and positive skews
2843         skews = [-3, -1, 0, 0.5]
2844         x_eval = 0.5
2845         neg_inf = -30  # avoid RuntimeWarning caused by np.log(0)
2846         cdfs = stats.pearson3.cdf(x_eval, skews)
2847         int_pdfs = [quad(stats.pearson3(skew).pdf, neg_inf, x_eval)[0]
2848                     for skew in skews]
2849         assert_allclose(cdfs, int_pdfs)
2850 
2851     def test_return_array_bug_11746(self):
2852         # pearson3.moment was returning size 0 or 1 array instead of float
2853         # The first moment is equal to the loc, which defaults to zero
2854         moment = stats.pearson3.moment(1, 2)
2855         assert_equal(moment, 0)
2856         assert isinstance(moment, np.number)
2857 
2858         moment = stats.pearson3.moment(1, 0.000001)
2859         assert_equal(moment, 0)
2860         assert isinstance(moment, np.number)
2861 
2862     def test_ppf_bug_17050(self):
2863         # incorrect PPF for negative skews were reported in gh-17050
2864         # Check that this is fixed (even in the array case)
2865         skews = [-3, -1, 0, 0.5]
2866         x_eval = 0.5
2867         res = stats.pearson3.ppf(stats.pearson3.cdf(x_eval, skews), skews)
2868         assert_allclose(res, x_eval)
2869 
2870         # Negation of the skew flips the distribution about the origin, so
2871         # the following should hold
2872         skew = np.array([[-0.5], [1.5]])
2873         x = np.linspace(-2, 2)
2874         assert_allclose(stats.pearson3.pdf(x, skew),
2875                         stats.pearson3.pdf(-x, -skew))
2876         assert_allclose(stats.pearson3.cdf(x, skew),
2877                         stats.pearson3.sf(-x, -skew))
2878         assert_allclose(stats.pearson3.ppf(x, skew),
2879                         -stats.pearson3.isf(x, -skew))
2880 
2881     def test_sf(self):
2882         # reference values were computed via the reference distribution, e.g.
2883         # mp.dps = 50; Pearson3(skew=skew).sf(x). Check positive, negative,
2884         # and zero skew due to branching.
2885         skew = [0.1, 0.5, 1.0, -0.1]
2886         x = [5.0, 10.0, 50.0, 8.0]
2887         ref = [1.64721926440872e-06, 8.271911573556123e-11,
2888                1.3149506021756343e-40, 2.763057937820296e-21]
2889         assert_allclose(stats.pearson3.sf(x, skew), ref, rtol=2e-14)
2890         assert_allclose(stats.pearson3.sf(x, 0), stats.norm.sf(x), rtol=2e-14)
2891 
2892 
2893 class TestKappa4:
2894     def test_cdf_genpareto(self):
2895         # h = 1 and k != 0 is generalized Pareto
2896         x = [0.0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5]
2897         h = 1.0
2898         for k in [-1.9, -1.0, -0.5, -0.2, -0.1, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0,
2899                   1.9]:
2900             vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2901             # shape parameter is opposite what is expected
2902             vals_comp = stats.genpareto.cdf(x, -k)
2903             assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2904 
2905     def test_cdf_genextreme(self):
2906         # h = 0 and k != 0 is generalized extreme value
2907         x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 10)
2908         h = 0.0
2909         k = np.linspace(-3, 3, 10)
2910         vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2911         vals_comp = stats.genextreme.cdf(x, k)
2912         assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2913 
2914     def test_cdf_expon(self):
2915         # h = 1 and k = 0 is exponential
2916         x = np.linspace(0, 10, 10)
2917         h = 1.0
2918         k = 0.0
2919         vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2920         vals_comp = stats.expon.cdf(x)
2921         assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2922 
2923     def test_cdf_gumbel_r(self):
2924         # h = 0 and k = 0 is gumbel_r
2925         x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 10)
2926         h = 0.0
2927         k = 0.0
2928         vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2929         vals_comp = stats.gumbel_r.cdf(x)
2930         assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2931 
2932     def test_cdf_logistic(self):
2933         # h = -1 and k = 0 is logistic
2934         x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 10)
2935         h = -1.0
2936         k = 0.0
2937         vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2938         vals_comp = stats.logistic.cdf(x)
2939         assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2940 
2941     def test_cdf_uniform(self):
2942         # h = 1 and k = 1 is uniform
2943         x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 10)
2944         h = 1.0
2945         k = 1.0
2946         vals = stats.kappa4.cdf(x, h, k)
2947         vals_comp = stats.uniform.cdf(x)
2948         assert_allclose(vals, vals_comp)
2949 
2950     def test_integers_ctor(self):
2951         # regression test for gh-7416: _argcheck fails for integer h and k
2952         # in numpy 1.12
2953         stats.kappa4(1, 2)
2954 
2955 
2956 class TestPoisson:
2957     def setup_method(self):
2958         np.random.seed(1234)
2959 
2960     def test_pmf_basic(self):
2961         # Basic case
2962         ln2 = np.log(2)
2963         vals = stats.poisson.pmf([0, 1, 2], ln2)
2964         expected = [0.5, ln2/2, ln2**2/4]
2965         assert_allclose(vals, expected)
2966 
2967     def test_mu0(self):
2968         # Edge case: mu=0
2969         vals = stats.poisson.pmf([0, 1, 2], 0)
2970         expected = [1, 0, 0]
2971         assert_array_equal(vals, expected)
2972 
2973         interval = stats.poisson.interval(0.95, 0)
2974         assert_equal(interval, (0, 0))
2975 
2976     def test_rvs(self):
2977         vals = stats.poisson.rvs(0.5, size=(2, 50))
2978         assert np.all(vals >= 0)
2979         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
2980         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2981         val = stats.poisson.rvs(0.5)
2982         assert isinstance(val, int)
2983         val = stats.poisson(0.5).rvs(3)
2984         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
2985         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
2986 
2987     def test_stats(self):
2988         mu = 16.0
2989         result = stats.poisson.stats(mu, moments='mvsk')
2990         assert_allclose(result, [mu, mu, np.sqrt(1.0/mu), 1.0/mu])
2991 
2992         mu = np.array([0.0, 1.0, 2.0])
2993         result = stats.poisson.stats(mu, moments='mvsk')
2994         expected = (mu, mu, [np.inf, 1, 1/np.sqrt(2)], [np.inf, 1, 0.5])
2995         assert_allclose(result, expected)
2996 
2997 
2998 class TestKSTwo:
2999     def setup_method(self):
3000         np.random.seed(1234)
3001 
3002     def test_cdf(self):
3003         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3004             # Test x-values:
3005             #  0, 1/2n, where the cdf should be 0
3006             #  1/n, where the cdf should be n!/n^n
3007             #  0.5, where the cdf should match ksone.cdf
3008             # 1-1/n, where cdf = 1-2/n^n
3009             # 1, where cdf == 1
3010             # (E.g. Exact values given by Eqn 1 in Simard / L'Ecuyer)
3011             x = np.array([0, 0.5/n, 1/n, 0.5, 1-1.0/n, 1])
3012             v1 = (1.0/n)**n
3013             lg = scipy.special.gammaln(n+1)
3014             elg = (np.exp(lg) if v1 != 0 else 0)
3015             expected = np.array([0, 0, v1 * elg,
3016                                  1 - 2*stats.ksone.sf(0.5, n),
3017                                  max(1 - 2*v1, 0.0),
3018                                  1.0])
3019             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(x, n)
3020             assert_allclose(vals_cdf, expected)
3021 
3022     def test_sf(self):
3023         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3024         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3025             # Same x values as in test_cdf, and use sf = 1 - cdf
3026             x = np.array([0, 0.5/n, 1/n, 0.5, 1-1.0/n, 1])
3027             v1 = (1.0/n)**n
3028             lg = scipy.special.gammaln(n+1)
3029             elg = (np.exp(lg) if v1 != 0 else 0)
3030             expected = np.array([1.0, 1.0,
3031                                  1 - v1 * elg,
3032                                  2*stats.ksone.sf(0.5, n),
3033                                  min(2*v1, 1.0), 0])
3034             vals_sf = stats.kstwo.sf(x, n)
3035             assert_allclose(vals_sf, expected)
3036 
3037     def test_cdf_sqrtn(self):
3038         # For fixed a, cdf(a/sqrt(n), n) -> kstwobign(a) as n->infinity
3039         # cdf(a/sqrt(n), n) is an increasing function of n (and a)
3040         # Check that the function is indeed increasing (allowing for some
3041         # small floating point and algorithm differences.)
3042         x = np.linspace(0, 2, 11)[1:]
3043         ns = [50, 100, 200, 400, 1000, 2000]
3044         for _x in x:
3045             xn = _x / np.sqrt(ns)
3046             probs = stats.kstwo.cdf(xn, ns)
3047             diffs = np.diff(probs)
3048             assert_array_less(diffs, 1e-8)
3049 
3050     def test_cdf_sf(self):
3051         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3052         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3053             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(x, n)
3054             vals_sf = stats.kstwo.sf(x, n)
3055             assert_array_almost_equal(vals_cdf, 1 - vals_sf)
3056 
3057     def test_cdf_sf_sqrtn(self):
3058         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3059         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3060             xn = x / np.sqrt(n)
3061             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(xn, n)
3062             vals_sf = stats.kstwo.sf(xn, n)
3063             assert_array_almost_equal(vals_cdf, 1 - vals_sf)
3064 
3065     def test_ppf_of_cdf(self):
3066         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3067         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3068             xn = x[x > 0.5/n]
3069             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(xn, n)
3070             # CDFs close to 1 are better dealt with using the SF
3071             cond = (0 < vals_cdf) & (vals_cdf < 0.99)
3072             vals = stats.kstwo.ppf(vals_cdf, n)
3073             assert_allclose(vals[cond], xn[cond], rtol=1e-4)
3074 
3075     def test_isf_of_sf(self):
3076         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3077         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3078             xn = x[x > 0.5/n]
3079             vals_isf = stats.kstwo.isf(xn, n)
3080             cond = (0 < vals_isf) & (vals_isf < 1.0)
3081             vals = stats.kstwo.sf(vals_isf, n)
3082             assert_allclose(vals[cond], xn[cond], rtol=1e-4)
3083 
3084     def test_ppf_of_cdf_sqrtn(self):
3085         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3086         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3087             xn = (x / np.sqrt(n))[x > 0.5/n]
3088             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(xn, n)
3089             cond = (0 < vals_cdf) & (vals_cdf < 1.0)
3090             vals = stats.kstwo.ppf(vals_cdf, n)
3091             assert_allclose(vals[cond], xn[cond])
3092 
3093     def test_isf_of_sf_sqrtn(self):
3094         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)
3095         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3096             xn = (x / np.sqrt(n))[x > 0.5/n]
3097             vals_sf = stats.kstwo.sf(xn, n)
3098             # SFs close to 1 are better dealt with using the CDF
3099             cond = (0 < vals_sf) & (vals_sf < 0.95)
3100             vals = stats.kstwo.isf(vals_sf, n)
3101             assert_allclose(vals[cond], xn[cond])
3102 
3103     def test_ppf(self):
3104         probs = np.linspace(0, 1, 11)[1:]
3105         for n in [1, 2, 3, 10, 100, 1000]:
3106             xn = stats.kstwo.ppf(probs, n)
3107             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(xn, n)
3108             assert_allclose(vals_cdf, probs)
3109 
3110     def test_simard_lecuyer_table1(self):
3111         # Compute the cdf for values near the mean of the distribution.
3112         # The mean u ~ log(2)*sqrt(pi/(2n))
3113         # Compute for x in [u/4, u/3, u/2, u, 2u, 3u]
3114         # This is the computation of Table 1 of Simard, R., L'Ecuyer, P. (2011)
3115         #  "Computing the Two-Sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov Distribution".
3116         # Except that the values below are not from the published table, but
3117         # were generated using an independent SageMath implementation of
3118         # Durbin's algorithm (with the exponentiation and scaling of
3119         # Marsaglia/Tsang/Wang's version) using 500 bit arithmetic.
3120         # Some of the values in the published table have relative
3121         # errors greater than 1e-4.
3122         ns = [10, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000]
3123         ratios = np.array([1.0/4, 1.0/3, 1.0/2, 1, 2, 3])
3124         expected = np.array([
3125             [1.92155292e-08, 5.72933228e-05, 2.15233226e-02, 6.31566589e-01,
3126              9.97685592e-01, 9.99999942e-01],
3127             [2.28096224e-09, 1.99142563e-05, 1.42617934e-02, 5.95345542e-01,
3128              9.96177701e-01, 9.99998662e-01],
3129             [1.00201886e-09, 1.32673079e-05, 1.24608594e-02, 5.86163220e-01,
3130              9.95866877e-01, 9.99998240e-01],
3131             [4.93313022e-10, 9.52658029e-06, 1.12123138e-02, 5.79486872e-01,
3132              9.95661824e-01, 9.99997964e-01],
3133             [2.37049293e-10, 6.85002458e-06, 1.01309221e-02, 5.73427224e-01,
3134              9.95491207e-01, 9.99997750e-01],
3135             [1.56990874e-10, 5.71738276e-06, 9.59725430e-03, 5.70322692e-01,
3136              9.95409545e-01, 9.99997657e-01]
3137         ])
3138         for idx, n in enumerate(ns):
3139             x = ratios * np.log(2) * np.sqrt(np.pi/2/n)
3140             vals_cdf = stats.kstwo.cdf(x, n)
3141             assert_allclose(vals_cdf, expected[idx], rtol=1e-5)
3142 
3143 
3144 class TestZipf:
3145     def setup_method(self):
3146         np.random.seed(1234)
3147 
3148     def test_rvs(self):
3149         vals = stats.zipf.rvs(1.5, size=(2, 50))
3150         assert np.all(vals >= 1)
3151         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
3152         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
3153         val = stats.zipf.rvs(1.5)
3154         assert isinstance(val, int)
3155         val = stats.zipf(1.5).rvs(3)
3156         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
3157         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
3158 
3159     def test_moments(self):
3160         # n-th moment is finite iff a > n + 1
3161         m, v = stats.zipf.stats(a=2.8)
3162         assert_(np.isfinite(m))
3163         assert_equal(v, np.inf)
3164 
3165         s, k = stats.zipf.stats(a=4.8, moments='sk')
3166         assert_(not np.isfinite([s, k]).all())
3167 
3168 
3169 class TestDLaplace:
3170     def setup_method(self):
3171         np.random.seed(1234)
3172 
3173     def test_rvs(self):
3174         vals = stats.dlaplace.rvs(1.5, size=(2, 50))
3175         assert np.shape(vals) == (2, 50)
3176         assert vals.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
3177         val = stats.dlaplace.rvs(1.5)
3178         assert isinstance(val, int)
3179         val = stats.dlaplace(1.5).rvs(3)
3180         assert isinstance(val, np.ndarray)
3181         assert val.dtype.char in typecodes['AllInteger']
3182         assert stats.dlaplace.rvs(0.8) is not None
3183 
3184     def test_stats(self):
3185         # compare the explicit formulas w/ direct summation using pmf
3186         a = 1.
3187         dl = stats.dlaplace(a)
3188         m, v, s, k = dl.stats('mvsk')
3189 
3190         N = 37
3191         xx = np.arange(-N, N+1)
3192         pp = dl.pmf(xx)
3193         m2, m4 = np.sum(pp*xx**2), np.sum(pp*xx**4)
3194         assert_equal((m, s), (0, 0))
3195         assert_allclose((v, k), (m2, m4/m2**2 - 3.), atol=1e-14, rtol=1e-8)
3196 
3197     def test_stats2(self):
3198         a = np.log(2.)
3199         dl = stats.dlaplace(a)
3200         m, v, s, k = dl.stats('mvsk')
3201         assert_equal((m, s), (0., 0.))
3202         assert_allclose((v, k), (4., 3.25))
3203 
3204 
3205 class TestInvgauss:
3206     def setup_method(self):
3207         np.random.seed(1234)
3208 
3209     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_mu,rvs_loc,rvs_scale",
3210                              [(2, 0, 1), (4.635, 4.362, 6.303)])
3211     def test_fit(self, rvs_mu, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
3212         data = stats.invgauss.rvs(size=100, mu=rvs_mu,
3213                                   loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale)
3214         # Analytical MLEs are calculated with formula when `floc` is fixed
3215         mu, loc, scale = stats.invgauss.fit(data, floc=rvs_loc)
3216 
3217         data = data - rvs_loc
3218         mu_temp = np.mean(data)
3219         scale_mle = len(data) / (np.sum(data**(-1) - mu_temp**(-1)))
3220         mu_mle = mu_temp/scale_mle
3221 
3222         # `mu` and `scale` match analytical formula
3223         assert_allclose(mu_mle, mu, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3224         assert_allclose(scale_mle, scale, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3225         assert_equal(loc, rvs_loc)
3226         data = stats.invgauss.rvs(size=100, mu=rvs_mu,
3227                                   loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale)
3228         # fixed parameters are returned
3229         mu, loc, scale = stats.invgauss.fit(data, floc=rvs_loc - 1,
3230                                             fscale=rvs_scale + 1)
3231         assert_equal(rvs_scale + 1, scale)
3232         assert_equal(rvs_loc - 1, loc)
3233 
3234         # shape can still be fixed with multiple names
3235         shape_mle1 = stats.invgauss.fit(data, fmu=1.04)[0]
3236         shape_mle2 = stats.invgauss.fit(data, fix_mu=1.04)[0]
3237         shape_mle3 = stats.invgauss.fit(data, f0=1.04)[0]
3238         assert shape_mle1 == shape_mle2 == shape_mle3 == 1.04
3239 
3240     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_mu,rvs_loc,rvs_scale",
3241                              [(2, 0, 1), (6.311, 3.225, 4.520)])
3242     def test_fit_MLE_comp_optimizer(self, rvs_mu, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
3243         rng = np.random.RandomState(1234)
3244         data = stats.invgauss.rvs(size=100, mu=rvs_mu,
3245                                   loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale, random_state=rng)
3246 
3247         super_fit = super(type(stats.invgauss), stats.invgauss).fit
3248         # fitting without `floc` uses superclass fit method
3249         super_fitted = super_fit(data)
3250         invgauss_fit = stats.invgauss.fit(data)
3251         assert_equal(super_fitted, invgauss_fit)
3252 
3253         # fitting with `fmu` is uses superclass fit method
3254         super_fitted = super_fit(data, floc=0, fmu=2)
3255         invgauss_fit = stats.invgauss.fit(data, floc=0, fmu=2)
3256         assert_equal(super_fitted, invgauss_fit)
3257 
3258         # fixed `floc` uses analytical formula and provides better fit than
3259         # super method
3260         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.invgauss, data, floc=rvs_loc)
3261 
3262         # fixed `floc` not resulting in invalid data < 0 uses analytical
3263         # formulas and provides a better fit than the super method
3264         assert np.all((data - (rvs_loc - 1)) > 0)
3265         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.invgauss, data, floc=rvs_loc - 1)
3266 
3267         # fixed `floc` to an arbitrary number, 0, still provides a better fit
3268         # than the super method
3269         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.invgauss, data, floc=0)
3270 
3271         # fixed `fscale` to an arbitrary number still provides a better fit
3272         # than the super method
3273         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.invgauss, data, floc=rvs_loc,
3274                                       fscale=np.random.rand(1)[0])
3275 
3276     def test_fit_raise_errors(self):
3277         assert_fit_warnings(stats.invgauss)
3278         # FitDataError is raised when negative invalid data
3279         with pytest.raises(FitDataError):
3280             stats.invgauss.fit([1, 2, 3], floc=2)
3281 
3282     def test_cdf_sf(self):
3283         # Regression tests for gh-13614.
3284         # Ground truth from R's statmod library (pinvgauss), e.g.
3285         # library(statmod)
3286         # options(digits=15)
3287         # mu = c(4.17022005e-04, 7.20324493e-03, 1.14374817e-06,
3288         #        3.02332573e-03, 1.46755891e-03)
3289         # print(pinvgauss(5, mu, 1))
3290 
3291         # make sure a finite value is returned when mu is very small. see
3292         # GH-13614
3293         mu = [4.17022005e-04, 7.20324493e-03, 1.14374817e-06,
3294               3.02332573e-03, 1.46755891e-03]
3295         expected = [1, 1, 1, 1, 1]
3296         actual = stats.invgauss.cdf(0.4, mu=mu)
3297         assert_equal(expected, actual)
3298 
3299         # test if the function can distinguish small left/right tail
3300         # probabilities from zero.
3301         cdf_actual = stats.invgauss.cdf(0.001, mu=1.05)
3302         assert_allclose(cdf_actual, 4.65246506892667e-219)
3303         sf_actual = stats.invgauss.sf(110, mu=1.05)
3304         assert_allclose(sf_actual, 4.12851625944048e-25)
3305 
3306         # test if x does not cause numerical issues when mu is very small
3307         # and x is close to mu in value.
3308 
3309         # slightly smaller than mu
3310         actual = stats.invgauss.cdf(0.00009, 0.0001)
3311         assert_allclose(actual, 2.9458022894924e-26)
3312 
3313         # slightly bigger than mu
3314         actual = stats.invgauss.cdf(0.000102, 0.0001)
3315         assert_allclose(actual, 0.976445540507925)
3316 
3317     def test_logcdf_logsf(self):
3318         # Regression tests for improvements made in gh-13616.
3319         # Ground truth from R's statmod library (pinvgauss), e.g.
3320         # library(statmod)
3321         # options(digits=15)
3322         # print(pinvgauss(0.001, 1.05, 1, log.p=TRUE, lower.tail=FALSE))
3323 
3324         # test if logcdf and logsf can compute values too small to
3325         # be represented on the unlogged scale. See: gh-13616
3326         logcdf = stats.invgauss.logcdf(0.0001, mu=1.05)
3327         assert_allclose(logcdf, -5003.87872590367)
3328         logcdf = stats.invgauss.logcdf(110, 1.05)
3329         assert_allclose(logcdf, -4.12851625944087e-25)
3330         logsf = stats.invgauss.logsf(0.001, mu=1.05)
3331         assert_allclose(logsf, -4.65246506892676e-219)
3332         logsf = stats.invgauss.logsf(110, 1.05)
3333         assert_allclose(logsf, -56.1467092416426)
3334 
3335     # from mpmath import mp
3336     # mp.dps = 100
3337     # mu = mp.mpf(1e-2)
3338     # ref = (1/2 * mp.log(2 * mp.pi * mp.e * mu**3)
3339     #        - 3/2* mp.exp(2/mu) * mp.e1(2/mu))
3340     @pytest.mark.parametrize("mu, ref", [(2e-8, -25.172361826883957),
3341                                          (1e-3, -8.943444010642972),
3342                                          (1e-2, -5.4962796152622335),
3343                                          (1e8, 3.3244822568873476),
3344                                          (1e100, 3.32448280139689)])
3345     def test_entropy(self, mu, ref):
3346         assert_allclose(stats.invgauss.entropy(mu), ref, rtol=5e-14)
3347 
3348 
3349 class TestLandau:
3350     @pytest.mark.parametrize('name', ['pdf', 'cdf', 'sf', 'ppf', 'isf'])
3351     def test_landau_levy_agreement(self, name):
3352         # Test PDF to confirm that this is the Landau distribution
3353         # Test other methods with tighter tolerance than generic tests
3354         # Levy entropy is slow and inaccurate, and RVS is tested generically
3355         if name in {'ppf', 'isf'}:
3356             x = np.linspace(0.1, 0.9, 5),
3357         else:
3358             x = np.linspace(-2, 5, 10),
3359 
3360         landau_method = getattr(stats.landau, name)
3361         levy_method = getattr(stats.levy_stable, name)
3362         res = landau_method(*x)
3363         ref = levy_method(*x, 1, 1)
3364         assert_allclose(res, ref, rtol=1e-14)
3365 
3366     def test_moments(self):
3367         # I would test these against Levy above, but Levy says variance is infinite.
3368         assert_equal(stats.landau.stats(moments='mvsk'), (np.nan,)*4)
3369         assert_equal(stats.landau.moment(5), np.nan)
3370 
3371 
3372 class TestLaplace:
3373     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc", [-5, 0, 1, 2])
3374     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_scale", [1, 2, 3, 10])
3375     def test_fit(self, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
3376         # tests that various inputs follow expected behavior
3377         # for a variety of `loc` and `scale`.
3378         rng = np.random.RandomState(1234)
3379         data = stats.laplace.rvs(size=100, loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale,
3380                                  random_state=rng)
3381 
3382         # MLE estimates are given by
3383         loc_mle = np.median(data)
3384         scale_mle = np.sum(np.abs(data - loc_mle)) / len(data)
3385 
3386         # standard outputs should match analytical MLE formulas
3387         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data)
3388         assert_allclose(loc, loc_mle, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3389         assert_allclose(scale, scale_mle, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3390 
3391         # fixed parameter should use analytical formula for other
3392         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, floc=loc_mle)
3393         assert_allclose(scale, scale_mle, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3394         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, fscale=scale_mle)
3395         assert_allclose(loc, loc_mle)
3396 
3397         # test with non-mle fixed parameter
3398         # create scale with non-median loc
3399         loc = rvs_loc * 2
3400         scale_mle = np.sum(np.abs(data - loc)) / len(data)
3401 
3402         # fixed loc to non median, scale should match
3403         # scale calculation with modified loc
3404         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, floc=loc)
3405         assert_equal(scale_mle, scale)
3406 
3407         # fixed scale created with non median loc,
3408         # loc output should still be the data median.
3409         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, fscale=scale_mle)
3410         assert_equal(loc_mle, loc)
3411 
3412         # error raised when both `floc` and `fscale` are fixed
3413         assert_raises(RuntimeError, stats.laplace.fit, data, floc=loc_mle,
3414                       fscale=scale_mle)
3415 
3416         # error is raised with non-finite values
3417         assert_raises(ValueError, stats.laplace.fit, [np.nan])
3418         assert_raises(ValueError, stats.laplace.fit, [np.inf])
3419 
3420     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc,rvs_scale", [(-5, 10),
3421                                                    (10, 5),
3422                                                    (0.5, 0.2)])
3423     def test_fit_MLE_comp_optimizer(self, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
3424         rng = np.random.RandomState(1234)
3425         data = stats.laplace.rvs(size=1000, loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale,
3426                                  random_state=rng)
3427 
3428         # the log-likelihood function for laplace is given by
3429         def ll(loc, scale, data):
3430             return -1 * (- (len(data)) * np.log(2*scale) -
3431                          (1/scale)*np.sum(np.abs(data - loc)))
3432 
3433         # test that the objective function result of the analytical MLEs is
3434         # less than or equal to that of the numerically optimized estimate
3435         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data)
3436         loc_opt, scale_opt = super(type(stats.laplace),
3437                                    stats.laplace).fit(data)
3438         ll_mle = ll(loc, scale, data)
3439         ll_opt = ll(loc_opt, scale_opt, data)
3440         assert ll_mle < ll_opt or np.allclose(ll_mle, ll_opt,
3441                                               atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3442 
3443     def test_fit_simple_non_random_data(self):
3444         data = np.array([1.0, 1.0, 3.0, 5.0, 8.0, 14.0])
3445         # with `floc` fixed to 6, scale should be 4.
3446         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, floc=6)
3447         assert_allclose(scale, 4, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3448         # with `fscale` fixed to 6, loc should be 4.
3449         loc, scale = stats.laplace.fit(data, fscale=6)
3450         assert_allclose(loc, 4, atol=1e-15, rtol=1e-15)
3451 
3452     def test_sf_cdf_extremes(self):
3453         # These calculations should not generate warnings.
3454         x = 1000
3455         p0 = stats.laplace.cdf(-x)
3456         # The exact value is smaller than can be represented with
3457         # 64 bit floating point, so the expected result is 0.
3458         assert p0 == 0.0
3459         # The closest 64 bit floating point representation of the
3460         # exact value is 1.0.
3461         p1 = stats.laplace.cdf(x)
3462         assert p1 == 1.0
3463 
3464         p0 = stats.laplace.sf(x)
3465         # The exact value is smaller than can be represented with
3466         # 64 bit floating point, so the expected result is 0.
3467         assert p0 == 0.0
3468         # The closest 64 bit floating point representation of the
3469         # exact value is 1.0.
3470         p1 = stats.laplace.sf(-x)
3471         assert p1 == 1.0
3472 
3473     def test_sf(self):
3474         x = 200
3475         p = stats.laplace.sf(x)
3476         assert_allclose(p, np.exp(-x)/2, rtol=1e-13)
3477 
3478     def test_isf(self):
3479         p = 1e-25
3480         x = stats.laplace.isf(p)
3481         assert_allclose(x, -np.log(2*p), rtol=1e-13)
3482 
3483     def test_logcdf_logsf(self):
3484         x = 40
3485         # Reference value computed with mpmath.
3486         ref = -2.1241771276457944e-18
3487         logcdf = stats.laplace.logcdf(x)
3488         assert_allclose(logcdf, ref)
3489         logsf = stats.laplace.logsf(-x)
3490         assert_allclose(logsf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
3491 
3492 
3493 class TestLogLaplace:
3494 
3495     def test_sf(self):
3496         # reference values were computed via the reference distribution, e.g.
3497         # mp.dps = 100; LogLaplace(c=c).sf(x).
3498         c = np.array([2.0, 3.0, 5.0])
3499         x = np.array([1e-5, 1e10, 1e15])
3500         ref = [0.99999999995, 5e-31, 5e-76]
3501         assert_allclose(stats.loglaplace.sf(x, c), ref, rtol=1e-15)
3502 
3503     def test_isf(self):
3504         # reference values were computed via the reference distribution, e.g.
3505         # mp.dps = 100; LogLaplace(c=c).isf(q).
3506         c = 3.25
3507         q = [0.8, 0.1, 1e-10, 1e-20, 1e-40]
3508         ref = [0.7543222539245642, 1.6408455124660906, 964.4916294395846,
3509                1151387.578354072, 1640845512466.0906]
3510         assert_allclose(stats.loglaplace.isf(q, c), ref, rtol=1e-14)
3511 
3512     @pytest.mark.parametrize('r', [1, 2, 3, 4])
3513     def test_moments_stats(self, r):
3514         mom = 'mvsk'[r - 1]
3515         c = np.arange(0.5, r + 0.5, 0.5)
3516 
3517         # r-th non-central moment is infinite if |r| >= c.
3518         assert_allclose(stats.loglaplace.moment(r, c), np.inf)
3519 
3520         # r-th non-central moment is non-finite (inf or nan) if r >= c.
3521         assert not np.any(np.isfinite(stats.loglaplace.stats(c, moments=mom)))
3522 
3523     @pytest.mark.parametrize("c", [0.5, 1.0, 2.0])
3524     @pytest.mark.parametrize("loc, scale", [(-1.2, 3.45)])
3525     @pytest.mark.parametrize("fix_c", [True, False])
3526     @pytest.mark.parametrize("fix_scale", [True, False])
3527     def test_fit_analytic_mle(self, c, loc, scale, fix_c, fix_scale):
3528         # Test that the analytical MLE produces no worse result than the
3529         # generic (numerical) MLE.
3530 
3531         rng = np.random.default_rng(6762668991392531563)
3532         data = stats.loglaplace.rvs(c, loc=loc, scale=scale, size=100,
3533                                     random_state=rng)
3534 
3535         kwds = {'floc': loc}
3536         if fix_c:
3537             kwds['fc'] = c
3538         if fix_scale:
3539             kwds['fscale'] = scale
3540         nfree = 3 - len(kwds)
3541 
3542         if nfree == 0:
3543             error_msg = "All parameters fixed. There is nothing to optimize."
3544             with pytest.raises((RuntimeError, ValueError), match=error_msg):
3545                 stats.loglaplace.fit(data, **kwds)
3546             return
3547 
3548         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.loglaplace, data, **kwds)
3549 
3550 
3551 class TestPowerlaw:
3552 
3553     # In the following data, `sf` was computed with mpmath.
3554     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, a, sf',
3555                              [(0.25, 2.0, 0.9375),
3556                               (0.99609375, 1/256, 1.528855235208108e-05)])
3557     def test_sf(self, x, a, sf):
3558         assert_allclose(stats.powerlaw.sf(x, a), sf, rtol=1e-15)
3559 
3560     @pytest.fixture(scope='function')
3561     def rng(self):
3562         return np.random.default_rng(1234)
3563 
3564     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_shape", [.1, .5, .75, 1, 2])
3565     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc", [-1, 0, 1])
3566     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_scale", [.1, 1, 5])
3567     @pytest.mark.parametrize('fix_shape, fix_loc, fix_scale',
3568                              [p for p in product([True, False], repeat=3)
3569                               if False in p])
