7131     #             / (fac1*mp.gamma((n+1)/2)))
7132     #     trm2 = (mp.hyp1f1((n+1)/2, 0.5, valF)
7133     #             / (mp.sqrt(fac1)*mp.gamma(n/2 + mp.one)))
7134     #     Px *= trm1+trm2
7135     #     return float(Px)
7136 
7137     @pytest.mark.parametrize("x, df, nc, expected", [
7138         (10000, 10, 16, 3.394646922945872e-30),
7139         (-10, 8, 16, 4.282769500264159e-70)
7140         ])
7141     def test_pdf_large_nc(self, x, df, nc, expected):
7142         # gh-#20693 reported zero values for large `nc` values
7143         assert_allclose(stats.nct.pdf(x, df, nc), expected, rtol=1e-12)
7144 
7145 
7146 class TestRecipInvGauss:
7147 
7148     def test_pdf_endpoint(self):
7149         p = stats.recipinvgauss.pdf(0, 0.6)
7150         assert p == 0.0
7151 
7152     def test_logpdf_endpoint(self):
7153         logp = stats.recipinvgauss.logpdf(0, 0.6)
7154         assert logp == -np.inf
7155 
7156     def test_cdf_small_x(self):
7157         # The expected value was computer with mpmath:
7158         #
7159         # import mpmath
7160         #
7161         # mpmath.mp.dps = 100
7162         #
7163         # def recipinvgauss_cdf_mp(x, mu):
7164         #     x = mpmath.mpf(x)
7165         #     mu = mpmath.mpf(mu)
7166         #     trm1 = 1/mu - x
7167         #     trm2 = 1/mu + x
7168         #     isqx = 1/mpmath.sqrt(x)
7169         #     return (mpmath.ncdf(-isqx*trm1)
7170         #             - mpmath.exp(2/mu)*mpmath.ncdf(-isqx*trm2))
7171         #
7172         p = stats.recipinvgauss.cdf(0.05, 0.5)
7173         expected = 6.590396159501331e-20
7174         assert_allclose(p, expected, rtol=1e-14)
7175 
7176     def test_sf_large_x(self):
7177         # The expected value was computed with mpmath; see test_cdf_small.
7178         p = stats.recipinvgauss.sf(80, 0.5)
7179         expected = 2.699819200556787e-18
7180         assert_allclose(p, expected, 5e-15)
7181 
7182 
7183 class TestRice:
7184     def test_rice_zero_b(self):
7185         # rice distribution should work with b=0, cf gh-2164
7186         x = [0.2, 1., 5.]
7187         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.rice.pdf(x, b=0.)).all())
7188         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.rice.logpdf(x, b=0.)).all())
7189         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.rice.cdf(x, b=0.)).all())
7190         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.rice.logcdf(x, b=0.)).all())
7191 
7192         q = [0.1, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9]
7193         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.rice.ppf(q, b=0.)).all())
7194 
7195         mvsk = stats.rice.stats(0, moments='mvsk')
7196         assert_(np.isfinite(mvsk).all())
7197 
7198         # furthermore, pdf is continuous as b\to 0
7199         # rice.pdf(x, b\to 0) = x exp(-x^2/2) + O(b^2)
7200         # see e.g. Abramovich & Stegun 9.6.7 & 9.6.10
7201         b = 1e-8
7202         assert_allclose(stats.rice.pdf(x, 0), stats.rice.pdf(x, b),
7203                         atol=b, rtol=0)
7204 
7205     def test_rice_rvs(self):
7206         rvs = stats.rice.rvs
7207         assert_equal(rvs(b=3.).size, 1)
7208         assert_equal(rvs(b=3., size=(3, 5)).shape, (3, 5))
7209 
7210     def test_rice_gh9836(self):
7211         # test that gh-9836 is resolved; previously jumped to 1 at the end
7212 
7213         cdf = stats.rice.cdf(np.arange(10, 160, 10), np.arange(10, 160, 10))
7214         # Generated in R
7215         # library(VGAM)
7216         # options(digits=16)
7217         # x = seq(10, 150, 10)
7218         # print(price(x, sigma=1, vee=x))
7219         cdf_exp = [0.4800278103504522, 0.4900233218590353, 0.4933500379379548,
7220                    0.4950128317658719, 0.4960103776798502, 0.4966753655438764,
7221                    0.4971503395812474, 0.4975065620443196, 0.4977836197921638,
7222                    0.4980052636649550, 0.4981866072661382, 0.4983377260666599,
7223                    0.4984655952615694, 0.4985751970541413, 0.4986701850071265]
7224         assert_allclose(cdf, cdf_exp)
7225 
7226         probabilities = np.arange(0.1, 1, 0.1)
7227         ppf = stats.rice.ppf(probabilities, 500/4, scale=4)
7228         # Generated in R
7229         # library(VGAM)
7230         # options(digits=16)
7231         # p = seq(0.1, .9, by = .1)
7232         # print(qrice(p, vee = 500, sigma = 4))
7233         ppf_exp = [494.8898762347361, 496.6495690858350, 497.9184315188069,
7234                    499.0026277378915, 500.0159999146250, 501.0293721352668,
7235                    502.1135684981884, 503.3824312270405, 505.1421247157822]
7236         assert_allclose(ppf, ppf_exp)
7237 
7238         ppf = scipy.stats.rice.ppf(0.5, np.arange(10, 150, 10))
7239         # Generated in R
7240         # library(VGAM)
7241         # options(digits=16)
7242         # b <- seq(10, 140, 10)
7243         # print(qrice(0.5, vee = b, sigma = 1))
7244         ppf_exp = [10.04995862522287, 20.02499480078302, 30.01666512465732,
7245                    40.01249934924363, 50.00999966676032, 60.00833314046875,
7246                    70.00714273568241, 80.00624991862573, 90.00555549840364,
7247                    100.00499995833597, 110.00454542324384, 120.00416664255323,
7248                    130.00384613488120, 140.00357141338748]
7249         assert_allclose(ppf, ppf_exp)
7250 
7251 
7252 class TestErlang:
7253     def setup_method(self):
7254         np.random.seed(1234)
7255 
7256     def test_erlang_runtimewarning(self):
7257         # erlang should generate a RuntimeWarning if a non-integer
7258         # shape parameter is used.
7259         with warnings.catch_warnings():
7260             warnings.simplefilter("error", RuntimeWarning)
7261 
7262             # The non-integer shape parameter 1.3 should trigger a
7263             # RuntimeWarning
7264             assert_raises(RuntimeWarning,
7265                           stats.erlang.rvs, 1.3, loc=0, scale=1, size=4)
7266 
7267             # Calling the fit method with `f0` set to an integer should
7268             # *not* trigger a RuntimeWarning.  It should return the same
7269             # values as gamma.fit(...).
7270             data = [0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0]
7271             result_erlang = stats.erlang.fit(data, f0=1)
7272             result_gamma = stats.gamma.fit(data, f0=1)
7273             assert_allclose(result_erlang, result_gamma, rtol=1e-3)
7274 
7275     def test_gh_pr_10949_argcheck(self):
7276         assert_equal(stats.erlang.pdf(0.5, a=[1, -1]),
7277                      stats.gamma.pdf(0.5, a=[1, -1]))
7278 
7279 
7280 class TestRayleigh:
7281     def setup_method(self):
7282         np.random.seed(987654321)
7283 
7284     # gh-6227
7285     def test_logpdf(self):
7286         y = stats.rayleigh.logpdf(50)
7287         assert_allclose(y, -1246.0879769945718)
7288 
7289     def test_logsf(self):
7290         y = stats.rayleigh.logsf(50)
7291         assert_allclose(y, -1250)
7292 
7293     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc,rvs_scale", [(0.85373171, 0.86932204),
7294                                                    (0.20558821, 0.61621008)])
7295     def test_fit(self, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
7296         data = stats.rayleigh.rvs(size=250, loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale)
7297 
7298         def scale_mle(data, floc):
7299             return (np.sum((data - floc) ** 2) / (2 * len(data))) ** .5
7300 
7301         # when `floc` is provided, `scale` is found with an analytical formula
7302         scale_expect = scale_mle(data, rvs_loc)
7303         loc, scale = stats.rayleigh.fit(data, floc=rvs_loc)
7304         assert_equal(loc, rvs_loc)
7305         assert_equal(scale, scale_expect)
7306 
7307         # when `fscale` is fixed, superclass fit is used to determine `loc`.
7308         loc, scale = stats.rayleigh.fit(data, fscale=.6)
7309         assert_equal(scale, .6)
7310 
7311         # with both parameters free, one dimensional optimization is done
7312         # over a new function that takes into account the dependent relation
7313         # of `scale` to `loc`.
7314         loc, scale = stats.rayleigh.fit(data)
7315         # test that `scale` is defined by its relation to `loc`
7316         assert_equal(scale, scale_mle(data, loc))
7317 
7318     @pytest.mark.parametrize("rvs_loc,rvs_scale", [[0.74, 0.01],
7319                                                    [0.08464463, 0.12069025]])
7320     def test_fit_comparison_super_method(self, rvs_loc, rvs_scale):
7321         # test that the objective function result of the analytical MLEs is
7322         # less than or equal to that of the numerically optimized estimate
7323         data = stats.rayleigh.rvs(size=250, loc=rvs_loc, scale=rvs_scale)
7324         _assert_less_or_close_loglike(stats.rayleigh, data)
7325 
7326     def test_fit_warnings(self):
7327         assert_fit_warnings(stats.rayleigh)
7328 
7329     def test_fit_gh17088(self):
7330         # `rayleigh.fit` could return a location that was inconsistent with
7331         # the data. See gh-17088.
7332         rng = np.random.default_rng(456)
7333         loc, scale, size = 50, 600, 500
7334         rvs = stats.rayleigh.rvs(loc, scale, size=size, random_state=rng)
7335         loc_fit, _ = stats.rayleigh.fit(rvs)
7336         assert loc_fit < np.min(rvs)
7337         loc_fit, scale_fit = stats.rayleigh.fit(rvs, fscale=scale)
7338         assert loc_fit < np.min(rvs)
7339         assert scale_fit == scale
7340 
7341 
7342 class TestExponWeib:
7343 
7344     def test_pdf_logpdf(self):
7345         # Regression test for gh-3508.
7346         x = 0.1
7347         a = 1.0
7348         c = 100.0
7349         p = stats.exponweib.pdf(x, a, c)
7350         logp = stats.exponweib.logpdf(x, a, c)
7351         # Expected values were computed with mpmath.
7352         assert_allclose([p, logp],
7353                         [1.0000000000000054e-97, -223.35075402042244])
7354 
7355     def test_a_is_1(self):
7356         # For issue gh-3508.
7357         # Check that when a=1, the pdf and logpdf methods of exponweib are the
7358         # same as those of weibull_min.
7359         x = np.logspace(-4, -1, 4)
7360         a = 1
7361         c = 100
7362 
7363         p = stats.exponweib.pdf(x, a, c)
7364         expected = stats.weibull_min.pdf(x, c)
7365         assert_allclose(p, expected)
7366 
7367         logp = stats.exponweib.logpdf(x, a, c)
7368         expected = stats.weibull_min.logpdf(x, c)
7369         assert_allclose(logp, expected)
7370 
7371     def test_a_is_1_c_is_1(self):
7372         # When a = 1 and c = 1, the distribution is exponential.
7373         x = np.logspace(-8, 1, 10)
7374         a = 1
7375         c = 1
7376 
7377         p = stats.exponweib.pdf(x, a, c)
7378         expected = stats.expon.pdf(x)
7379         assert_allclose(p, expected)
7380 
7381         logp = stats.exponweib.logpdf(x, a, c)
7382         expected = stats.expon.logpdf(x)
7383         assert_allclose(logp, expected)
7384 
7385     # Reference values were computed with mpmath, e.g:
7386     #
7387     #     from mpmath import mp
7388     #
7389     #     def mp_sf(x, a, c):
7390     #         x = mp.mpf(x)
7391     #         a = mp.mpf(a)
7392     #         c = mp.mpf(c)
7393     #         return -mp.powm1(-mp.expm1(-x**c)), a)
7394     #
7395     #     mp.dps = 100
7396     #     print(float(mp_sf(1, 2.5, 0.75)))
7397     #
7398     # prints
7399     #
7400     #     0.6823127476985246
7401     #
7402     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
7403         'x, a, c, ref',
7404         [(1, 2.5, 0.75, 0.6823127476985246),
7405          (50, 2.5, 0.75, 1.7056666054719663e-08),
7406          (125, 2.5, 0.75, 1.4534393150714602e-16),
7407          (250, 2.5, 0.75, 1.2391389689773512e-27),
7408          (250, 0.03125, 0.75, 1.548923711221689e-29),
7409          (3, 0.03125, 3.0,  5.873527551689983e-14),
7410          (2e80, 10.0, 0.02, 2.9449084156902135e-17)]
7411     )
7412     def test_sf(self, x, a, c, ref):
7413         sf = stats.exponweib.sf(x, a, c)
7414         assert_allclose(sf, ref, rtol=1e-14)
7415 
7416     # Reference values were computed with mpmath, e.g.
7417     #
7418     #     from mpmath import mp
7419     #
7420     #     def mp_isf(p, a, c):
7421     #         p = mp.mpf(p)
7422     #         a = mp.mpf(a)
7423     #         c = mp.mpf(c)
7424     #         return (-mp.log(-mp.expm1(mp.log1p(-p)/a)))**(1/c)
7425     #
7426     #     mp.dps = 100
7427     #     print(float(mp_isf(0.25, 2.5, 0.75)))
7428     #
7429     # prints
7430     #
7431     #     2.8946008178158924
7432     #
7433     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
7434         'p, a, c, ref',
7435         [(0.25, 2.5, 0.75, 2.8946008178158924),
7436          (3e-16, 2.5, 0.75, 121.77966713102938),
7437          (1e-12, 1, 2, 5.256521769756932),
7438          (2e-13, 0.03125, 3, 2.953915059484589),
7439          (5e-14, 10.0, 0.02, 7.57094886384687e+75)]
7440     )
7441     def test_isf(self, p, a, c, ref):
7442         isf = stats.exponweib.isf(p, a, c)
7443         assert_allclose(isf, ref, rtol=5e-14)
7444 
7445     # Reference values computed with mpmath.
7446     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, a, c, ref',
7447                              [(2, 3, 8, -1.9848783170128456e-111),
7448                               (1000, 0.5, 0.75, -2.946296827524972e-78)])
7449     def test_logcdf(self, x, a, c, ref):
7450         logcdf = stats.exponweib.logcdf(x, a, c)
7451         assert_allclose(logcdf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
7452 
7453     # Reference values computed with mpmath.
7454     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, a, c, ref',
7455                              [(1e-65, 1.5, 1.25, -1.333521432163324e-122),
7456                               (2e-10, 2, 10, -1.0485760000000007e-194)])
7457     def test_logsf(self, x, a, c, ref):
7458         logsf = stats.exponweib.logsf(x, a, c)
7459         assert_allclose(logsf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
7460 
7461 
7462 class TestFatigueLife:
7463 
7464     def test_sf_tail(self):
7465         # Expected value computed with mpmath:
7466         #     import mpmath
7467         #     mpmath.mp.dps = 80
7468         #     x = mpmath.mpf(800.0)
7469         #     c = mpmath.mpf(2.5)
7470         #     s = float(1 - mpmath.ncdf(1/c * (mpmath.sqrt(x)
7471         #                                      - 1/mpmath.sqrt(x))))
7472         #     print(s)
7473         # Output:
7474         #     6.593376447038406e-30
7475         s = stats.fatiguelife.sf(800.0, 2.5)
7476         assert_allclose(s, 6.593376447038406e-30, rtol=1e-13)
7477 
7478     def test_isf_tail(self):
7479         # See test_sf_tail for the mpmath code.
7480         p = 6.593376447038406e-30
7481         q = stats.fatiguelife.isf(p, 2.5)
7482         assert_allclose(q, 800.0, rtol=1e-13)
7483 
7484 
7485 class TestWeibull:
7486 
7487     def test_logpdf(self):
7488         # gh-6217
7489         y = stats.weibull_min.logpdf(0, 1)
7490         assert_equal(y, 0)
7491 
7492     def test_with_maxima_distrib(self):
7493         # Tests for weibull_min and weibull_max.
7494         # The expected values were computed using the symbolic algebra
7495         # program 'maxima' with the package 'distrib', which has
7496         # 'pdf_weibull' and 'cdf_weibull'.  The mapping between the
7497         # scipy and maxima functions is as follows:
7498         # -----------------------------------------------------------------
7499         # scipy                              maxima
7500         # ---------------------------------  ------------------------------
7501         # weibull_min.pdf(x, a, scale=b)     pdf_weibull(x, a, b)
7502         # weibull_min.logpdf(x, a, scale=b)  log(pdf_weibull(x, a, b))
7503         # weibull_min.cdf(x, a, scale=b)     cdf_weibull(x, a, b)
7504         # weibull_min.logcdf(x, a, scale=b)  log(cdf_weibull(x, a, b))
7505         # weibull_min.sf(x, a, scale=b)      1 - cdf_weibull(x, a, b)
7506         # weibull_min.logsf(x, a, scale=b)   log(1 - cdf_weibull(x, a, b))
7507         #
7508         # weibull_max.pdf(x, a, scale=b)     pdf_weibull(-x, a, b)
7509         # weibull_max.logpdf(x, a, scale=b)  log(pdf_weibull(-x, a, b))
7510         # weibull_max.cdf(x, a, scale=b)     1 - cdf_weibull(-x, a, b)
7511         # weibull_max.logcdf(x, a, scale=b)  log(1 - cdf_weibull(-x, a, b))
7512         # weibull_max.sf(x, a, scale=b)      cdf_weibull(-x, a, b)
7513         # weibull_max.logsf(x, a, scale=b)   log(cdf_weibull(-x, a, b))
7514         # -----------------------------------------------------------------
7515         x = 1.5
7516         a = 2.0
7517         b = 3.0
7518 
7519         # weibull_min
7520 
7521         p = stats.weibull_min.pdf(x, a, scale=b)
7522         assert_allclose(p, np.exp(-0.25)/3)
7523 
7524         lp = stats.weibull_min.logpdf(x, a, scale=b)
7525         assert_allclose(lp, -0.25 - np.log(3))
7526 
7527         c = stats.weibull_min.cdf(x, a, scale=b)
7528         assert_allclose(c, -special.expm1(-0.25))
7529 
7530         lc = stats.weibull_min.logcdf(x, a, scale=b)
7531         assert_allclose(lc, np.log(-special.expm1(-0.25)))
7532 
7533         s = stats.weibull_min.sf(x, a, scale=b)
7534         assert_allclose(s, np.exp(-0.25))
7535 
7536         ls = stats.weibull_min.logsf(x, a, scale=b)
7537         assert_allclose(ls, -0.25)
7538 
7539         # Also test using a large value x, for which computing the survival
7540         # function using the CDF would result in 0.
7541         s = stats.weibull_min.sf(30, 2, scale=3)
7542         assert_allclose(s, np.exp(-100))
7543 
7544         ls = stats.weibull_min.logsf(30, 2, scale=3)
7545         assert_allclose(ls, -100)
7546 
7547         # weibull_max
7548         x = -1.5
7549 
7550         p = stats.weibull_max.pdf(x, a, scale=b)
7551         assert_allclose(p, np.exp(-0.25)/3)
7552 
7553         lp = stats.weibull_max.logpdf(x, a, scale=b)
7554         assert_allclose(lp, -0.25 - np.log(3))
7555 
7556         c = stats.weibull_max.cdf(x, a, scale=b)
7557         assert_allclose(c, np.exp(-0.25))
7558 
7559         lc = stats.weibull_max.logcdf(x, a, scale=b)
7560         assert_allclose(lc, -0.25)
7561 
7562         s = stats.weibull_max.sf(x, a, scale=b)
7563         assert_allclose(s, -special.expm1(-0.25))
7564 
7565         ls = stats.weibull_max.logsf(x, a, scale=b)
7566         assert_allclose(ls, np.log(-special.expm1(-0.25)))
7567 
7568         # Also test using a value of x close to 0, for which computing the
7569         # survival function using the CDF would result in 0.
7570         s = stats.weibull_max.sf(-1e-9, 2, scale=3)
7571         assert_allclose(s, -special.expm1(-1/9000000000000000000))
7572 
7573         ls = stats.weibull_max.logsf(-1e-9, 2, scale=3)
7574         assert_allclose(ls, np.log(-special.expm1(-1/9000000000000000000)))
7575 
7576     @pytest.mark.parametrize('scale', [1.0, 0.1])
7577     def test_delta_cdf(self, scale):
7578         # Expected value computed with mpmath:
7579         #
7580         # def weibull_min_sf(x, k, scale):
7581         #     x = mpmath.mpf(x)
7582         #     k = mpmath.mpf(k)
7583         #     scale =mpmath.mpf(scale)
7584         #     return mpmath.exp(-(x/scale)**k)
7585         #
7586         # >>> import mpmath
7587         # >>> mpmath.mp.dps = 60
7588         # >>> sf1 = weibull_min_sf(7.5, 3, 1)
7589         # >>> sf2 = weibull_min_sf(8.0, 3, 1)
7590         # >>> float(sf1 - sf2)
7591         # 6.053624060118734e-184
7592         #
7593         delta = stats.weibull_min._delta_cdf(scale*7.5, scale*8, 3,
7594                                              scale=scale)
7595         assert_allclose(delta, 6.053624060118734e-184)
7596 
7597     def test_fit_min(self):
7598         rng = np.random.default_rng(5985959307161735394)
7599 
7600         c, loc, scale = 2, 3.5, 0.5  # arbitrary, valid parameters
7601         dist = stats.weibull_min(c, loc, scale)
7602         rvs = dist.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng)
7603 
7604         # test that MLE still honors guesses and fixed parameters
7605         c2, loc2, scale2 = stats.weibull_min.fit(rvs, 1.5, floc=3)
7606         c3, loc3, scale3 = stats.weibull_min.fit(rvs, 1.6, floc=3)
7607         assert loc2 == loc3 == 3  # fixed parameter is respected
7608         assert c2 != c3  # different guess -> (slightly) different outcome
7609         # quality of fit is tested elsewhere
7610 
7611         # test that MoM honors fixed parameters, accepts (but ignores) guesses
7612         c4, loc4, scale4 = stats.weibull_min.fit(rvs, 3, fscale=3, method='mm')
7613         assert scale4 == 3
7614         # because scale was fixed, only the mean and skewness will be matched
7615         dist4 = stats.weibull_min(c4, loc4, scale4)
7616         res = dist4.stats(moments='ms')
7617         ref = np.mean(rvs), stats.skew(rvs)
7618         assert_allclose(res, ref)
7619 
7620     # reference values were computed via mpmath
7621     # from mpmath import mp
7622     # def weibull_sf_mpmath(x, c):
7623     #     x = mp.mpf(x)
7624     #     c = mp.mpf(c)
7625     #     return float(mp.exp(-x**c))
7626 
7627     @pytest.mark.parametrize('x, c, ref', [(50, 1, 1.9287498479639178e-22),
7628                                            (1000, 0.8,
7629                                             8.131269637872743e-110)])
7630     def test_sf_isf(self, x, c, ref):
7631         assert_allclose(stats.weibull_min.sf(x, c), ref, rtol=5e-14)
7632         assert_allclose(stats.weibull_min.isf(ref, c), x, rtol=5e-14)
7633 
7634 
7635 class TestDweibull:
7636     def test_entropy(self):
7637         # Test that dweibull entropy follows that of weibull_min.
7638         # (Generic tests check that the dweibull entropy is consistent
7639         #  with its PDF. As for accuracy, dweibull entropy should be just
7640         #  as accurate as weibull_min entropy. Checks of accuracy against
7641         #  a reference need only be applied to the fundamental distribution -
7642         #  weibull_min.)
7643         rng = np.random.default_rng(8486259129157041777)
7644         c = 10**rng.normal(scale=100, size=10)
7645         res = stats.dweibull.entropy(c)
7646         ref = stats.weibull_min.entropy(c) - np.log(0.5)
7647         assert_allclose(res, ref, rtol=1e-15)
7648 
7649     def test_sf(self):
7650         # test that for positive values the dweibull survival function is half
7651         # the weibull_min survival function
7652         rng = np.random.default_rng(8486259129157041777)
7653         c = 10**rng.normal(scale=1, size=10)
7654         x = 10 * rng.uniform()
7655         res = stats.dweibull.sf(x, c)
7656         ref = 0.5 * stats.weibull_min.sf(x, c)
7657         assert_allclose(res, ref, rtol=1e-15)
7658 
7659 
7660 class TestTruncWeibull:
7661 
7662     def test_pdf_bounds(self):
7663         # test bounds
7664         y = stats.truncweibull_min.pdf([0.1, 2.0], 2.0, 0.11, 1.99)
7665         assert_equal(y, [0.0, 0.0])
7666 
7667     def test_logpdf(self):
7668         y = stats.truncweibull_min.logpdf(2.0, 1.0, 2.0, np.inf)
7669         assert_equal(y, 0.0)
7670 
7671         # hand calculation
7672         y = stats.truncweibull_min.logpdf(2.0, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0)
7673         assert_allclose(y, 0.14541345786885884)
7674 
7675     def test_ppf_bounds(self):
7676         # test bounds
7677         y = stats.truncweibull_min.ppf([0.0, 1.0], 2.0, 0.1, 2.0)
7678         assert_equal(y, [0.1, 2.0])
7679 
7680     def test_cdf_to_ppf(self):
7681         q = [0., 0.1, .25, 0.50, 0.75, 0.90, 1.]
7682         x = stats.truncweibull_min.ppf(q, 2., 0., 3.)
7683         q_out = stats.truncweibull_min.cdf(x, 2., 0., 3.)
7684         assert_allclose(q, q_out)
7685 
7686     def test_sf_to_isf(self):
7687         q = [0., 0.1, .25, 0.50, 0.75, 0.90, 1.]
7688         x = stats.truncweibull_min.isf(q, 2., 0., 3.)
7689         q_out = stats.truncweibull_min.sf(x, 2., 0., 3.)
7690         assert_allclose(q, q_out)
7691 
7692     def test_munp(self):
7693         c = 2.
7694         a = 1.
7695         b = 3.
7696 
7697         def xnpdf(x, n):
7698             return x**n*stats.truncweibull_min.pdf(x, c, a, b)
7699 
7700         m0 = stats.truncweibull_min.moment(0, c, a, b)
7701         assert_equal(m0, 1.)
7702 
7703         m1 = stats.truncweibull_min.moment(1, c, a, b)
7704         m1_expected, _ = quad(lambda x: xnpdf(x, 1), a, b)
7705         assert_allclose(m1, m1_expected)
7706 
7707         m2 = stats.truncweibull_min.moment(2, c, a, b)
7708         m2_expected, _ = quad(lambda x: xnpdf(x, 2), a, b)
7709         assert_allclose(m2, m2_expected)
7710 
7711         m3 = stats.truncweibull_min.moment(3, c, a, b)
7712         m3_expected, _ = quad(lambda x: xnpdf(x, 3), a, b)
7713         assert_allclose(m3, m3_expected)
7714 
7715         m4 = stats.truncweibull_min.moment(4, c, a, b)
7716         m4_expected, _ = quad(lambda x: xnpdf(x, 4), a, b)
7717         assert_allclose(m4, m4_expected)
7718 
7719     def test_reference_values(self):
7720         a = 1.
7721         b = 3.
7722         c = 2.
7723         x_med = np.sqrt(1 - np.log(0.5 + np.exp(-(8. + np.log(2.)))))
7724 
7725         cdf = stats.truncweibull_min.cdf(x_med, c, a, b)
7726         assert_allclose(cdf, 0.5)
7727 
7728         lc = stats.truncweibull_min.logcdf(x_med, c, a, b)
7729         assert_allclose(lc, -np.log(2.))
7730 
7731         ppf = stats.truncweibull_min.ppf(0.5, c, a, b)
7732         assert_allclose(ppf, x_med)
7733 
7734         sf = stats.truncweibull_min.sf(x_med, c, a, b)
7735         assert_allclose(sf, 0.5)
7736 
7737         ls = stats.truncweibull_min.logsf(x_med, c, a, b)
7738         assert_allclose(ls, -np.log(2.))
7739 
7740         isf = stats.truncweibull_min.isf(0.5, c, a, b)
7741         assert_allclose(isf, x_med)
7742 
7743     def test_compare_weibull_min(self):
7744         # Verify that the truncweibull_min distribution gives the same results
7745         # as the original weibull_min
7746         x = 1.5
7747         c = 2.0
7748         a = 0.0
7749         b = np.inf
7750         scale = 3.0
7751 
7752         p = stats.weibull_min.pdf(x, c, scale=scale)
7753         p_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.pdf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7754         assert_allclose(p, p_trunc)
7755 
7756         lp = stats.weibull_min.logpdf(x, c, scale=scale)
7757         lp_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.logpdf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7758         assert_allclose(lp, lp_trunc)
7759 
7760         cdf = stats.weibull_min.cdf(x, c, scale=scale)
7761         cdf_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.cdf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7762         assert_allclose(cdf, cdf_trunc)
7763 
7764         lc = stats.weibull_min.logcdf(x, c, scale=scale)
7765         lc_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.logcdf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7766         assert_allclose(lc, lc_trunc)
7767 
7768         s = stats.weibull_min.sf(x, c, scale=scale)
7769         s_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.sf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7770         assert_allclose(s, s_trunc)
7771 
7772         ls = stats.weibull_min.logsf(x, c, scale=scale)
7773         ls_trunc = stats.truncweibull_min.logsf(x, c, a, b, scale=scale)
7774         assert_allclose(ls, ls_trunc)
7775 
7776         # # Also test using a large value x, for which computing the survival
7777         # # function using the CDF would result in 0.
7778         s = stats.truncweibull_min.sf(30, 2, a, b, scale=3)
7779         assert_allclose(s, np.exp(-100))
7780 
7781         ls = stats.truncweibull_min.logsf(30, 2, a, b, scale=3)
7782         assert_allclose(ls, -100)
7783 
7784     def test_compare_weibull_min2(self):
7785         # Verify that the truncweibull_min distribution PDF and CDF results
7786         # are the same as those calculated from truncating weibull_min
7787         c, a, b = 2.5, 0.25, 1.25
7788         x = np.linspace(a, b, 100)
7789 
7790         pdf1 = stats.truncweibull_min.pdf(x, c, a, b)
7791         cdf1 = stats.truncweibull_min.cdf(x, c, a, b)
7792 
7793         norm = stats.weibull_min.cdf(b, c) - stats.weibull_min.cdf(a, c)
7794         pdf2 = stats.weibull_min.pdf(x, c) / norm
7795         cdf2 = (stats.weibull_min.cdf(x, c) - stats.weibull_min.cdf(a, c))/norm
7796 
7797         np.testing.assert_allclose(pdf1, pdf2)
7798         np.testing.assert_allclose(cdf1, cdf2)
7799 
7800 
7801 class TestRdist:
7802     def test_rdist_cdf_gh1285(self):
7803         # check workaround in rdist._cdf for issue gh-1285.
7804         distfn = stats.rdist
7805         values = [0.001, 0.5, 0.999]
7806         assert_almost_equal(distfn.cdf(distfn.ppf(values, 541.0), 541.0),
7807                             values, decimal=5)
7808 
7809     def test_rdist_beta(self):
7810         # rdist is a special case of stats.beta
7811         x = np.linspace(-0.99, 0.99, 10)
7812         c = 2.7
7813         assert_almost_equal(0.5*stats.beta(c/2, c/2).pdf((x + 1)/2),
7814                             stats.rdist(c).pdf(x))
7815 
7816     # reference values were computed via mpmath
7817     # from mpmath import mp
7818     # mp.dps = 200
7819     # def rdist_sf_mpmath(x, c):
7820     #     x = mp.mpf(x)
7821     #     c = mp.mpf(c)
7822     #     return float(mp.betainc(c/2, c/2, (x+1)/2, mp.one, regularized=True))
7823     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
7824         "x, c, ref",
7825         [
7826             (0.0001, 541, 0.49907251345565845),
7827             (0.1, 241, 0.06000788166249205),
7828             (0.5, 441, 1.0655898106047832e-29),
7829             (0.8, 341, 6.025478373732215e-78),
7830         ]
7831     )
7832     def test_rdist_sf(self, x, c, ref):
7833         assert_allclose(stats.rdist.sf(x, c), ref, rtol=5e-14)
7834 
7835 
7836 class TestTrapezoid:
7837     def test_reduces_to_triang(self):
7838         modes = [0, 0.3, 0.5, 1]
7839         for mode in modes:
7840             x = [0, mode, 1]
7841             assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(x, mode, mode),
7842                                 stats.triang.pdf(x, mode))
7843             assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(x, mode, mode),
7844                                 stats.triang.cdf(x, mode))
7845 
7846     def test_reduces_to_uniform(self):
7847         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 10)
7848         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(x, 0, 1), stats.uniform.pdf(x))
7849         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(x, 0, 1), stats.uniform.cdf(x))
7850 
7851     def test_cases(self):
7852         # edge cases
7853         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0, 0, 0), 2)
7854         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(1, 1, 1), 2)
7855         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0.5, 0, 0.8),
7856                             1.11111111111111111)
7857         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0.5, 0.2, 1.0),
7858                             1.11111111111111111)
7859 
7860         # straightforward case
7861         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0.1, 0.2, 0.8), 0.625)
7862         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0.5, 0.2, 0.8), 1.25)
7863         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.pdf(0.9, 0.2, 0.8), 0.625)
7864 
7865         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(0.1, 0.2, 0.8), 0.03125)
7866         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(0.2, 0.2, 0.8), 0.125)
7867         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(0.5, 0.2, 0.8), 0.5)
7868         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(0.9, 0.2, 0.8), 0.96875)
7869         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.cdf(1.0, 0.2, 0.8), 1.0)
7870 
7871     def test_moments_and_entropy(self):
7872         # issue #11795: improve precision of trapezoid stats
7873         # Apply formulas from Wikipedia for the following parameters:
7874         a, b, c, d = -3, -1, 2, 3  # => 1/3, 5/6, -3, 6
7875         p1, p2, loc, scale = (b-a) / (d-a), (c-a) / (d-a), a, d-a
7876         h = 2 / (d+c-b-a)
7877 
7878         def moment(n):
7879             return (h * ((d**(n+2) - c**(n+2)) / (d-c)
7880                          - (b**(n+2) - a**(n+2)) / (b-a)) /
7881                     (n+1) / (n+2))
7882 
7883         mean = moment(1)
7884         var = moment(2) - mean**2
7885         entropy = 0.5 * (d-c+b-a) / (d+c-b-a) + np.log(0.5 * (d+c-b-a))
7886         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.mean(p1, p2, loc, scale),
7887                             mean, decimal=13)
7888         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.var(p1, p2, loc, scale),
7889                             var, decimal=13)
7890         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.entropy(p1, p2, loc, scale),
7891                             entropy, decimal=13)
7892 
7893         # Check boundary cases where scipy d=0 or d=1.
7894         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.mean(0, 0, -3, 6), -1, decimal=13)
7895         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.mean(0, 1, -3, 6), 0, decimal=13)
7896         assert_almost_equal(stats.trapezoid.var(0, 1, -3, 6), 3, decimal=13)
7897 
7898     def test_trapezoid_vect(self):
7899         # test that array-valued shapes and arguments are handled
7900         c = np.array([0.1, 0.2, 0.3])
7901         d = np.array([0.5, 0.6])[:, None]
7902         x = np.array([0.15, 0.25, 0.9])
7903         v = stats.trapezoid.pdf(x, c, d)
7904 
7905         cc, dd, xx = np.broadcast_arrays(c, d, x)
7906 
7907         res = np.empty(xx.size, dtype=xx.dtype)
7908         ind = np.arange(xx.size)
7909         for i, x1, c1, d1 in zip(ind, xx.ravel(), cc.ravel(), dd.ravel()):
7910             res[i] = stats.trapezoid.pdf(x1, c1, d1)
7911 
7912         assert_allclose(v, res.reshape(v.shape), atol=1e-15)
7913 
7914         # Check that the stats() method supports vector arguments.
7915         v = np.asarray(stats.trapezoid.stats(c, d, moments="mvsk"))
7916         cc, dd = np.broadcast_arrays(c, d)
7917         res = np.empty((cc.size, 4))  # 4 stats returned per value
7918         ind = np.arange(cc.size)
7919         for i, c1, d1 in zip(ind, cc.ravel(), dd.ravel()):
7920             res[i] = stats.trapezoid.stats(c1, d1, moments="mvsk")
7921 
7922         assert_allclose(v, res.T.reshape(v.shape), atol=1e-15)
7923 
7924     def test_trapz(self):
7925         # Basic test for alias
7926         x = np.linspace(0, 1, 10)
7927         with pytest.deprecated_call(match="`trapz.pdf` is deprecated"):
7928             result = stats.trapz.pdf(x, 0, 1)
7929         assert_almost_equal(result, stats.uniform.pdf(x))
7930 
7931     @pytest.mark.parametrize('method', ['pdf', 'logpdf', 'cdf', 'logcdf',
7932                                         'sf', 'logsf', 'ppf', 'isf'])
7933     def test_trapz_deprecation(self, method):
7934         c, d = 0.2, 0.8
7935         expected = getattr(stats.trapezoid, method)(1, c, d)
7936         with pytest.deprecated_call(
7937             match=f"`trapz.{method}` is deprecated",
7938         ):
7939             result = getattr(stats.trapz, method)(1, c, d)
7940         assert result == expected
7941 
7942 
7943 class TestTriang:
7944     def test_edge_cases(self):
7945         with np.errstate(all='raise'):
7946             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(0, 0), 2.)
7947             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(0.5, 0), 1.)
7948             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(1, 0), 0.)
7949 
7950             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(0, 1), 0)
7951             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(0.5, 1), 1.)
7952             assert_equal(stats.triang.pdf(1, 1), 2)
7953 
7954             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(0., 0.), 0.)
7955             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(0.5, 0.), 0.75)
7956             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(1.0, 0.), 1.0)
7957 
7958             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(0., 1.), 0.)
7959             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(0.5, 1.), 0.25)
7960             assert_equal(stats.triang.cdf(1., 1.), 1)
7961 
7962 
7963 class TestMaxwell:
7964 
7965     # reference values were computed with wolfram alpha
7966     # erfc(x/sqrt(2)) + sqrt(2/pi) * x * e^(-x^2/2)
7967 
7968     @pytest.mark.parametrize("x, ref",
7969                              [(20, 2.2138865931011177e-86),
7970                               (0.01, 0.999999734046458435)])
7971     def test_sf(self, x, ref):
7972         assert_allclose(stats.maxwell.sf(x), ref, rtol=1e-14)
7973 
7974     # reference values were computed with wolfram alpha
7975     # sqrt(2) * sqrt(Q^(-1)(3/2, q))
7976 
7977     @pytest.mark.parametrize("q, ref",
7978                              [(0.001, 4.033142223656157022),
7979                               (0.9999847412109375, 0.0385743284050381),
7980                               (2**-55, 8.95564974719481)])
7981     def test_isf(self, q, ref):
7982         assert_allclose(stats.maxwell.isf(q), ref, rtol=1e-15)
7983 
7984     def test_logcdf(self):
7985         # Reference value computed with mpmath.
7986         ref = -1.8729310110194814e-17
7987         logcdf = stats.maxwell.logcdf(9)
7988         assert_allclose(logcdf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
7989 
7990     def test_logsf(self):
7991         # Reference value computed with mpmath.
7992         ref = -2.6596152026762177e-25
7993         logsf = stats.maxwell.logsf(1e-8)
7994         assert_allclose(logsf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
7995 
7996 
7997 class TestMielke:
7998     def test_moments(self):
7999         k, s = 4.642, 0.597
8000         # n-th moment exists only if n < s
8001         assert_equal(stats.mielke(k, s).moment(1), np.inf)
8002         assert_equal(stats.mielke(k, 1.0).moment(1), np.inf)
8003         assert_(np.isfinite(stats.mielke(k, 1.01).moment(1)))
8004 
8005     def test_burr_equivalence(self):
8006         x = np.linspace(0.01, 100, 50)
8007         k, s = 2.45, 5.32
8008         assert_allclose(stats.burr.pdf(x, s, k/s), stats.mielke.pdf(x, k, s))
8009 
8010 
8011 class TestBurr:
8012     def test_endpoints_7491(self):
8013         # gh-7491
8014         # Compute the pdf at the left endpoint dst.a.
8015         data = [
8016             [stats.fisk, (1,), 1],
8017             [stats.burr, (0.5, 2), 1],
8018             [stats.burr, (1, 1), 1],
8019             [stats.burr, (2, 0.5), 1],
8020             [stats.burr12, (1, 0.5), 0.5],
8021             [stats.burr12, (1, 1), 1.0],
8022             [stats.burr12, (1, 2), 2.0]]
8023 
8024         ans = [_f.pdf(_f.a, *_args) for _f, _args, _ in data]
8025         correct = [_correct_ for _f, _args, _correct_ in data]
8026         assert_array_almost_equal(ans, correct)
8027 
8028         ans = [_f.logpdf(_f.a, *_args) for _f, _args, _ in data]
8029         correct = [np.log(_correct_) for _f, _args, _correct_ in data]
8030         assert_array_almost_equal(ans, correct)
8031 
8032     def test_burr_stats_9544(self):
8033         # gh-9544.  Test from gh-9978
8034         c, d = 5.0, 3
8035         mean, variance = stats.burr(c, d).stats()
8036         # mean = sc.beta(3 + 1/5, 1. - 1/5) * 3  = 1.4110263...
8037         # var =  sc.beta(3 + 2 / 5, 1. - 2 / 5) * 3 -
8038         #        (sc.beta(3 + 1 / 5, 1. - 1 / 5) * 3) ** 2
8039         mean_hc, variance_hc = 1.4110263183925857, 0.22879948026191643
8040         assert_allclose(mean, mean_hc)
8041         assert_allclose(variance, variance_hc)
8042 
8043     def test_burr_nan_mean_var_9544(self):
8044         # gh-9544.  Test from gh-9978
8045         c, d = 0.5, 3
8046         mean, variance = stats.burr(c, d).stats()
8047         assert_(np.isnan(mean))
8048         assert_(np.isnan(variance))
8049         c, d = 1.5, 3
8050         mean, variance = stats.burr(c, d).stats()
8051         assert_(np.isfinite(mean))
8052         assert_(np.isnan(variance))
8053 
8054         c, d = 0.5, 3
8055         e1, e2, e3, e4 = stats.burr._munp(np.array([1, 2, 3, 4]), c, d)
8056         assert_(np.isnan(e1))
8057         assert_(np.isnan(e2))
8058         assert_(np.isnan(e3))
8059         assert_(np.isnan(e4))
8060         c, d = 1.5, 3
8061         e1, e2, e3, e4 = stats.burr._munp([1, 2, 3, 4], c, d)
8062         assert_(np.isfinite(e1))
8063         assert_(np.isnan(e2))
8064         assert_(np.isnan(e3))
8065         assert_(np.isnan(e4))
8066         c, d = 2.5, 3
8067         e1, e2, e3, e4 = stats.burr._munp([1, 2, 3, 4], c, d)
8068         assert_(np.isfinite(e1))
8069         assert_(np.isfinite(e2))
8070         assert_(np.isnan(e3))
8071         assert_(np.isnan(e4))
8072         c, d = 3.5, 3
8073         e1, e2, e3, e4 = stats.burr._munp([1, 2, 3, 4], c, d)
8074         assert_(np.isfinite(e1))
8075         assert_(np.isfinite(e2))
8076         assert_(np.isfinite(e3))
8077         assert_(np.isnan(e4))
8078         c, d = 4.5, 3
8079         e1, e2, e3, e4 = stats.burr._munp([1, 2, 3, 4], c, d)
8080         assert_(np.isfinite(e1))
8081         assert_(np.isfinite(e2))
8082         assert_(np.isfinite(e3))
8083         assert_(np.isfinite(e4))
8084 
8085     def test_burr_isf(self):
8086         # reference values were computed via the reference distribution, e.g.
8087         # mp.dps = 100
8088         # Burr(c=5, d=3).isf([0.1, 1e-10, 1e-20, 1e-40])
8089         c, d = 5.0, 3.0
8090         q = [0.1, 1e-10, 1e-20, 1e-40]
8091         ref = [1.9469686558286508, 124.57309395989076, 12457.309396155173,
8092                124573093.96155174]
8093         assert_allclose(stats.burr.isf(q, c, d), ref, rtol=1e-14)
8094 
8095 
8096 class TestBurr12:
8097 
8098     @pytest.mark.parametrize('scale, expected',
8099                              [(1.0, 2.3283064359965952e-170),
8100                               (3.5, 5.987114417447875e-153)])
8101     def test_delta_cdf(self, scale, expected):
8102         # Expected value computed with mpmath:
8103         #
8104         # def burr12sf(x, c, d, scale):
8105         #     x = mpmath.mpf(x)
8106         #     c = mpmath.mpf(c)
8107         #     d = mpmath.mpf(d)
8108         #     scale = mpmath.mpf(scale)
8109         #     return (mpmath.mp.one + (x/scale)**c)**(-d)
8110         #
8111         # >>> import mpmath
8112         # >>> mpmath.mp.dps = 60
8113         # >>> float(burr12sf(2e5, 4, 8, 1) - burr12sf(4e5, 4, 8, 1))
8114         # 2.3283064359965952e-170
8115         # >>> float(burr12sf(2e5, 4, 8, 3.5) - burr12sf(4e5, 4, 8, 3.5))
8116         # 5.987114417447875e-153
8117         #
8118         delta = stats.burr12._delta_cdf(2e5, 4e5, 4, 8, scale=scale)
8119         assert_allclose(delta, expected, rtol=1e-13)
8120 
8121     def test_moments_edge(self):
8122         # gh-18838 reported that burr12 moments could be invalid; see above.
8123         # Check that this is resolved in an edge case where c*d == n, and
8124         # compare the results against those produced by Mathematica, e.g.
8125         # `SinghMaddalaDistribution[2, 2, 1]` at Wolfram Alpha.
8126         c, d = 2, 2
8127         mean = np.pi/4
8128         var = 1 - np.pi**2/16
8129         skew = np.pi**3/(32*var**1.5)
8130         kurtosis = np.nan
8131         ref = [mean, var, skew, kurtosis]
8132         res = stats.burr12(c, d).stats('mvsk')
8133         assert_allclose(res, ref, rtol=1e-14)
8134 
8135     # Reference values were computed with mpmath using mp.dps = 80
8136     # and then cast to float.
8137     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
8138         'p, c, d, ref',
8139         [(1e-12, 20, 0.5, 15.848931924611135),
8140          (1e-19, 20, 0.5, 79.43282347242815),
8141          (1e-12, 0.25, 35, 2.0888618213462466),
8142          (1e-80, 0.25, 35, 1360930951.7972188)]
8143     )
8144     def test_isf_near_zero(self, p, c, d, ref):
8145         x = stats.burr12.isf(p, c, d)
8146         assert_allclose(x, ref, rtol=1e-14)
8147 
8148 
8149 class TestStudentizedRange:
8150     # For alpha = .05, .01, and .001, and for each value of
8151     # v = [1, 3, 10, 20, 120, inf], a Q was picked from each table for
8152     # k = [2, 8, 14, 20].
8153 
8154     # these arrays are written with `k` as column, and `v` as rows.
8155     # Q values are taken from table 3:
8156     # https://www.jstor.org/stable/2237810
8157     q05 = [17.97, 45.40, 54.33, 59.56,
8158            4.501, 8.853, 10.35, 11.24,
8159            3.151, 5.305, 6.028, 6.467,
8160            2.950, 4.768, 5.357, 5.714,
8161            2.800, 4.363, 4.842, 5.126,
8162            2.772, 4.286, 4.743, 5.012]
8163     q01 = [90.03, 227.2, 271.8, 298.0,
8164            8.261, 15.64, 18.22, 19.77,
8165            4.482, 6.875, 7.712, 8.226,
8166            4.024, 5.839, 6.450, 6.823,
8167            3.702, 5.118, 5.562, 5.827,
8168            3.643, 4.987, 5.400, 5.645]
8169     q001 = [900.3, 2272, 2718, 2980,
8170             18.28, 34.12, 39.69, 43.05,
8171             6.487, 9.352, 10.39, 11.03,
8172             5.444, 7.313, 7.966, 8.370,
8173             4.772, 6.039, 6.448, 6.695,
8174             4.654, 5.823, 6.191, 6.411]
8175     qs = np.concatenate((q05, q01, q001))
8176     ps = [.95, .99, .999]
8177     vs = [1, 3, 10, 20, 120, np.inf]
8178     ks = [2, 8, 14, 20]
8179 
8180     data = list(zip(product(ps, vs, ks), qs))
8181 
8182     # A small selection of large-v cases generated with R's `ptukey`
8183     # Each case is in the format (q, k, v, r_result)
8184     r_data = [
8185         (0.1, 3, 9001, 0.002752818526842),
8186         (1, 10, 1000, 0.000526142388912),
8187         (1, 3, np.inf, 0.240712641229283),
8188         (4, 3, np.inf, 0.987012338626815),
8189         (1, 10, np.inf, 0.000519869467083),
8190     ]
8191 
8192     @pytest.mark.slow
8193     def test_cdf_against_tables(self):
8194         for pvk, q in self.data:
8195             p_expected, v, k = pvk
8196             res_p = stats.studentized_range.cdf(q, k, v)
8197             assert_allclose(res_p, p_expected, rtol=1e-4)
8198 
8199     @pytest.mark.xslow
8200     def test_ppf_against_tables(self):
8201         for pvk, q_expected in self.data:
8202             p, v, k = pvk
8203             res_q = stats.studentized_range.ppf(p, k, v)
8204             assert_allclose(res_q, q_expected, rtol=5e-4)
8205 
8206     path_prefix = os.path.dirname(__file__)
8207     relative_path = "data/studentized_range_mpmath_ref.json"
8208     with open(os.path.join(path_prefix, relative_path)) as file:
8209         pregenerated_data = json.load(file)
8210 
8211     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case_result", pregenerated_data["cdf_data"])
8212     def test_cdf_against_mp(self, case_result):
8213         src_case = case_result["src_case"]
8214         mp_result = case_result["mp_result"]
8215         qkv = src_case["q"], src_case["k"], src_case["v"]
8216         res = stats.studentized_range.cdf(*qkv)
8217 
8218         assert_allclose(res, mp_result,
8219                         atol=src_case["expected_atol"],
8220                         rtol=src_case["expected_rtol"])
8221 
8222     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case_result", pregenerated_data["pdf_data"])
8223     def test_pdf_against_mp(self, case_result):
8224         src_case = case_result["src_case"]
8225         mp_result = case_result["mp_result"]
8226         qkv = src_case["q"], src_case["k"], src_case["v"]
8227         res = stats.studentized_range.pdf(*qkv)
8228 
8229         assert_allclose(res, mp_result,
8230                         atol=src_case["expected_atol"],
8231                         rtol=src_case["expected_rtol"])
8232 
8233     @pytest.mark.xslow
8234     @pytest.mark.xfail_on_32bit("intermittent RuntimeWarning: invalid value.")
8235     @pytest.mark.parametrize("case_result", pregenerated_data["moment_data"])
8236     def test_moment_against_mp(self, case_result):
8237         src_case = case_result["src_case"]
8238         mp_result = case_result["mp_result"]
8239         mkv = src_case["m"], src_case["k"], src_case["v"]
8240 
8241         # Silence invalid value encountered warnings. Actual problems will be
8242         # caught by the result comparison.
8243         with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
8244             res = stats.studentized_range.moment(*mkv)
8245 
8246         assert_allclose(res, mp_result,
8247                         atol=src_case["expected_atol"],
8248                         rtol=src_case["expected_rtol"])
8249 
8250     @pytest.mark.slow
8251     def test_pdf_integration(self):
8252         k, v = 3, 10
8253         # Test whether PDF integration is 1 like it should be.
8254         res = quad(stats.studentized_range.pdf, 0, np.inf, args=(k, v))
8255         assert_allclose(res[0], 1)
8256 
8257     @pytest.mark.xslow
8258     def test_pdf_against_cdf(self):
8259         k, v = 3, 10
8260 
8261         # Test whether the integrated PDF matches the CDF using cumulative
8262         # integration. Use a small step size to reduce error due to the
8263         # summation. This is slow, but tests the results well.
8264         x = np.arange(0, 10, step=0.01)
8265 
8266         y_cdf = stats.studentized_range.cdf(x, k, v)[1:]
8267         y_pdf_raw = stats.studentized_range.pdf(x, k, v)
8268         y_pdf_cumulative = cumulative_trapezoid(y_pdf_raw, x)
8269 
8270         # Because of error caused by the summation, use a relatively large rtol
8271         assert_allclose(y_pdf_cumulative, y_cdf, rtol=1e-4)
8272 
8273     @pytest.mark.parametrize("r_case_result", r_data)
8274     def test_cdf_against_r(self, r_case_result):
8275         # Test large `v` values using R
8276         q, k, v, r_res = r_case_result
8277         with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
8278             res = stats.studentized_range.cdf(q, k, v)
8279         assert_allclose(res, r_res)
8280 
8281     @pytest.mark.xslow
8282     @pytest.mark.xfail_on_32bit("intermittent RuntimeWarning: invalid value.")
8283     def test_moment_vectorization(self):
8284         # Test moment broadcasting. Calls `_munp` directly because
8285         # `rv_continuous.moment` is broken at time of writing. See gh-12192
8286 
8287         # Silence invalid value encountered warnings. Actual problems will be
8288         # caught by the result comparison.
8289         with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
8290             m = stats.studentized_range._munp([1, 2], [4, 5], [10, 11])
8291 
8292         assert_allclose(m.shape, (2,))
8293 
8294         with pytest.raises(ValueError, match="...could not be broadcast..."):
8295             stats.studentized_range._munp(1, [4, 5], [10, 11, 12])
8296 
8297     @pytest.mark.xslow
8298     def test_fitstart_valid(self):
8299         with suppress_warnings() as sup, np.errstate(invalid="ignore"):
8300             # the integration warning message may differ
8301             sup.filter(IntegrationWarning)
8302             k, df, _, _ = stats.studentized_range._fitstart([1, 2, 3])
8303         assert_(stats.studentized_range._argcheck(k, df))
8304 
8305     def test_infinite_df(self):
8306         # Check that the CDF and PDF infinite and normal integrators
8307         # roughly match for a high df case
8308         res = stats.studentized_range.pdf(3, 10, np.inf)
8309         res_finite = stats.studentized_range.pdf(3, 10, 99999)
8310         assert_allclose(res, res_finite, atol=1e-4, rtol=1e-4)
8311 
8312         res = stats.studentized_range.cdf(3, 10, np.inf)
8313         res_finite = stats.studentized_range.cdf(3, 10, 99999)
8314         assert_allclose(res, res_finite, atol=1e-4, rtol=1e-4)
8315 
8316     def test_df_cutoff(self):
8317         # Test that the CDF and PDF properly switch integrators at df=100,000.
8318         # The infinite integrator should be different enough that it fails
8319         # an allclose assertion. Also sanity check that using the same
8320         # integrator does pass the allclose with a 1-df difference, which
8321         # should be tiny.
8322 
8323         res = stats.studentized_range.pdf(3, 10, 100000)
8324         res_finite = stats.studentized_range.pdf(3, 10, 99999)
8325         res_sanity = stats.studentized_range.pdf(3, 10, 99998)
8326         assert_raises(AssertionError, assert_allclose, res, res_finite,
8327                       atol=1e-6, rtol=1e-6)
8328         assert_allclose(res_finite, res_sanity, atol=1e-6, rtol=1e-6)
8329 
8330         res = stats.studentized_range.cdf(3, 10, 100000)
8331         res_finite = stats.studentized_range.cdf(3, 10, 99999)
8332         res_sanity = stats.studentized_range.cdf(3, 10, 99998)
8333         assert_raises(AssertionError, assert_allclose, res, res_finite,
8334                       atol=1e-6, rtol=1e-6)
8335         assert_allclose(res_finite, res_sanity, atol=1e-6, rtol=1e-6)
8336 
8337     def test_clipping(self):
8338         # The result of this computation was -9.9253938401489e-14 on some
8339         # systems. The correct result is very nearly zero, but should not be
8340         # negative.
8341         q, k, v = 34.6413996195345746, 3, 339
8342         p = stats.studentized_range.sf(q, k, v)
8343         assert_allclose(p, 0, atol=1e-10)
8344         assert p >= 0
8345 
8346 
8347 class TestTukeyLambda:
8348 
8349     @pytest.mark.parametrize(
8350         'lam',
8351         [0.0, -1.0, -2.0, np.array([[-1.0], [0.0], [-2.0]])]
8352     )
8353     def test_pdf_nonpositive_lambda(self, lam):
8354         # Make sure that Tukey-Lambda distribution correctly handles
8355         # non-positive lambdas.
8356         # This is a crude test--it just checks that all the PDF values
8357         # are finite and greater than 0.
8358         x = np.linspace(-5.0, 5.0, 101)
8359         p = stats.tukeylambda.pdf(x, lam)
8360         assert np.isfinite(p).all()
8361         assert (p > 0.0).all()
8362 
8363     def test_pdf_mixed_lambda(self):
8364         # Another crude test of the behavior of the PDF method.
8365         x = np.linspace(-5.0, 5.0, 101)
8366         lam = np.array([[-1.0], [0.0], [2.0]])
8367         p = stats.tukeylambda.pdf(x, lam)
8368         assert np.isfinite(p).all()
8369         # For p[0] and p[1], where lam <= 0, the support is (-inf, inf),
8370         # so the PDF should be nonzero everywhere (assuming we aren't so
8371         # far in the tails that we get underflow).
8372         assert (p[:2] > 0.0).all()
8373         # For p[2], where lam=2.0, the support is [-0.5, 0.5], so in pdf(x),
8374         # some values should be positive and some should be 0.
8375         assert (p[2] > 0.0).any()
8376         assert (p[2] == 0.0).any()
8377 
8378     def test_support(self):
8379         lam = np.array([-1.75, -0.5, 0.0, 0.25, 0.5, 2.0])
8380         a, b = stats.tukeylambda.support(lam)
8381         expected_b = np.array([np.inf, np.inf, np.inf, 4, 2, 0.5])
8382         assert_equal(b, expected_b)
8383         assert_equal(a, -expected_b)
8384 
8385     def test_pdf_support_boundary(self):
8386         # Verify that tukeylambda.pdf() doesn't generate a
8387         # warning when evaluated at the bounds of the support.
8388         # For lam=0.5, the support is (-2, 2).
8389         p = stats.tukeylambda.pdf([-2.0, 2.0], 0.5)
8390         assert_equal(p, [0.0, 0.0])
8391 
8392     def test_tukeylambda_stats_ticket_1545(self):
8393         # Some test for the variance and kurtosis of the Tukey Lambda distr.
8394         # See test_tukeylamdba_stats.py for more tests.
8395 
8396         mv = stats.tukeylambda.stats(0, moments='mvsk')
8397         # Known exact values:
8398         expected = [0, np.pi**2/3, 0, 1.2]
8399         assert_almost_equal(mv, expected, decimal=10)
8400 
8401         mv = stats.tukeylambda.stats(3.13, moments='mvsk')
8402         # 'expected' computed with mpmath.
8403         expected = [0, 0.0269220858861465102, 0, -0.898062386219224104]
8404         assert_almost_equal(mv, expected, decimal=10)
8405 
8406         mv = stats.tukeylambda.stats(0.14, moments='mvsk')
8407         # 'expected' computed with mpmath.
8408         expected = [0, 2.11029702221450250, 0, -0.02708377353223019456]
8409         assert_almost_equal(mv, expected, decimal=10)
8410 
8411 
8412 class TestLevy:
8413 
8414     def test_levy_cdf_ppf(self):
8415         # Test levy.cdf, including small arguments.
8416         x = np.array([1000, 1.0, 0.5, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001])
8417 
8418         # Expected values were calculated separately with mpmath.
8419         # E.g.
8420         # >>> mpmath.mp.dps = 100
8421         # >>> x = mpmath.mp.mpf('0.01')
8422         # >>> cdf = mpmath.erfc(mpmath.sqrt(1/(2*x)))
8423         expected = np.array([0.9747728793699604,
8424                              0.3173105078629141,
8425                              0.1572992070502851,
8426                              0.0015654022580025495,
8427                              1.523970604832105e-23,
8428                              1.795832784800726e-219])
8429 
8430         y = stats.levy.cdf(x)
8431         assert_allclose(y, expected, rtol=1e-10)
8432 
8433         # ppf(expected) should get us back to x.
8434         xx = stats.levy.ppf(expected)
8435         assert_allclose(xx, x, rtol=1e-13)
8436 
8437     def test_levy_sf(self):
8438         # Large values, far into the tail of the distribution.
8439         x = np.array([1e15, 1e25, 1e35, 1e50])
8440         # Expected values were calculated with mpmath.
8441         expected = np.array([2.5231325220201597e-08,
8442                              2.52313252202016e-13,
8443                              2.52313252202016e-18,
8444                              7.978845608028653e-26])
8445         y = stats.levy.sf(x)
8446         assert_allclose(y, expected, rtol=1e-14)
8447 
8448     # The expected values for levy.isf(p) were calculated with mpmath.
8449     # For loc=0 and scale=1, the inverse SF can be computed with
8450     #
8451     #     import mpmath
8452     #
8453     #     def levy_invsf(p):
8454     #         return 1/(2*mpmath.erfinv(p)**2)
8455     #
8456     # For example, with mpmath.mp.dps set to 60, float(levy_invsf(1e-20))
8457     # returns 6.366197723675814e+39.
8458     #
8459     @pytest.mark.parametrize('p, expected_isf',
8460                              [(1e-20, 6.366197723675814e+39),
8461                               (1e-8, 6366197723675813.0),
8462                               (0.375, 4.185810119346273),
8463                               (0.875, 0.42489442055310134),
8464                               (0.999, 0.09235685880262713),
8465                               (0.9999999962747097, 0.028766845244146945)])
8466     def test_levy_isf(self, p, expected_isf):
8467         x = stats.levy.isf(p)
8468         assert_allclose(x, expected_isf, atol=5e-15)
8469 
8470     def test_levy_logcdf(self):
8471         x = 1e50
8472         ref = -7.978845608028653e-26
8473         logcdf = stats.levy.logcdf(x)
8474         assert_allclose(logcdf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
8475 
8476     def test_levy_logsf(self):
8477         x = 5e-3
8478         ref = -2.0884875837625492e-45
8479         logsf = stats.levy.logsf(x)
8480         assert_allclose(logsf, ref, rtol=5e-15)
8481 
8482 
8483 def test_540_567():
8484     # test for nan returned in tickets 540, 567
8485     assert_almost_equal(stats.norm.cdf(-1.7624320982), 0.03899815971089126,
8486                         decimal=10, err_msg='test_540_567')
8487     assert_almost_equal(stats.norm.cdf(-1.7624320983), 0.038998159702449846,
8488                         decimal=10, err_msg='test_540_567')
8489     assert_almost_equal(stats.norm.cdf(1.38629436112, loc=0.950273420309,
8490                                        scale=0.204423758009),
8491                         0.98353464004309321,
8492                         decimal=10, err_msg='test_540_567')

8498     assert_('pmf(x,' in stats.poisson.__doc__)

8501 def test_nan_arguments_gh_issue_1362():
8502     with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
8503         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.logcdf(1, np.nan)))
8504         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.cdf(1, np.nan)))
8505         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.logsf(1, np.nan)))
8506         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.sf(1, np.nan)))
8507         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.pdf(1, np.nan)))
8508         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.logpdf(1, np.nan)))
8509         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.ppf(1, np.nan)))
8510         assert_(np.isnan(stats.t.isf(1, np.nan)))
8511 
8512         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.logcdf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8513         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.cdf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8514         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.logsf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8515         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.sf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8516         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.pmf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8517         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.logpmf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8518         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.ppf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8519         assert_(np.isnan(stats.bernoulli.isf(np.nan, 0.5)))
8520 
8521 
8522 def test_frozen_fit_ticket_1536():
8523     np.random.seed(5678)
8524     true = np.array([0.25, 0., 0.5])
8525     x = stats.lognorm.rvs(true[0], true[1], true[2], size=100)
8526 
8527     with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
8528         params = np.array(stats.lognorm.fit(x, floc=0.))
8529 
8530     assert_almost_equal(params, true, decimal=2)
8531 
8532     params = np.array(stats.lognorm.fit(x, fscale=0.5, loc=0))
8533     assert_almost_equal(params, true, decimal=2)
8534 
8535     params = np.array(stats.lognorm.fit(x, f0=0.25, loc=0))
8536     assert_almost_equal(params, true, decimal=2)
8537 
8538     params = np.array(stats.lognorm.fit(x, f0=0.25, floc=0))
8539     assert_almost_equal(params, true, decimal=2)
8540 
8541     np.random.seed(5678)
8542     loc = 1
8543     floc = 0.9
8544     x = stats.norm.rvs(loc, 2., size=100)
8545     params = np.array(stats.norm.fit(x, floc=floc))
8546     expected = np.array([floc, np.sqrt(((x-floc)**2).mean())])
8547     assert_almost_equal(params, expected, decimal=4)
8548 
8549 
8550 def test_regression_ticket_1530():
8551     # Check the starting value works for Cauchy distribution fit.
8552     np.random.seed(654321)
8553     rvs = stats.cauchy.rvs(size=100)
8554     params = stats.cauchy.fit(rvs)
8555     expected = (0.045, 1.142)
8556     assert_almost_equal(params, expected, decimal=1)

8558 
8559 def test_gh_pr_4806():
8560     # Check starting values for Cauchy distribution fit.
8561     np.random.seed(1234)
8562     x = np.random.randn(42)
8563     for offset in 10000.0, 1222333444.0:
8564         loc, scale = stats.cauchy.fit(x + offset)
8565         assert_allclose(loc, offset, atol=1.0)
8566         assert_allclose(scale, 0.6, atol=1.0)

8569 def test_poisson_logpmf_ticket_1436():
8570     assert_(np.isfinite(stats.poisson.logpmf(1500, 200)))
8571 
8572 
8573 def test_powerlaw_stats():
8574     """Test the powerlaw stats function. 
8575  
8576     This unit test is also a regression test for ticket 1548. 
8577  
8578     The exact values are: 
8579     mean: 
8580         mu = a / (a + 1) 
8581     variance: 
8582         sigma**2 = a / ((a + 2) * (a + 1) ** 2) 
8583     skewness: 
8584         One formula (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skewness) is 
8585             gamma_1 = (E[X**3] - 3*mu*E[X**2] + 2*mu**3) / sigma**3 
8586         A short calculation shows that E[X**k] is a / (a + k), so gamma_1 
8587         can be implemented as 
8588             n = a/(a+3) - 3*(a/(a+1))*a/(a+2) + 2*(a/(a+1))**3 
8589             d = sqrt(a/((a+2)*(a+1)**2)) ** 3 
8590             gamma_1 = n/d 
8591         Either by simplifying, or by a direct calculation of mu_3 / sigma**3, 
8592         one gets the more concise formula: 
8593             gamma_1 = -2.0 * ((a - 1) / (a + 3)) * sqrt((a + 2) / a) 
8594     kurtosis: (See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis) 
8595         The excess kurtosis is 
8596             gamma_2 = mu_4 / sigma**4 - 3 
8597         A bit of calculus and algebra (sympy helps) shows that 
8598             mu_4 = 3*a*(3*a**2 - a + 2) / ((a+1)**4 * (a+2) * (a+3) * (a+4)) 
8599         so 
8600             gamma_2 = 3*(3*a**2 - a + 2) * (a+2) / (a*(a+3)*(a+4)) - 3 
8601         which can be rearranged to 
8602             gamma_2 = 6 * (a**3 - a**2 - 6*a + 2) / (a*(a+3)*(a+4)) 
8603     """
8604     cases = [(1.0, (0.5, 1./12, 0.0, -1.2)),
8605              (2.0, (2./3, 2./36, -0.56568542494924734, -0.6))]
8606     for a, exact_mvsk in cases:
8607         mvsk = stats.powerlaw.stats(a, moments="mvsk")
8608         assert_array_almost_equal(mvsk, exact_mvsk)
8609 
8610 
8611 def test_powerlaw_edge():
8612     # Regression test for gh-3986.
8613     p = stats.powerlaw.logpdf(0, 1)
8614     assert_equal(p, 0.0)
8615 
8616 
8617 def test_exponpow_edge():
8618     # Regression test for gh-3982.
8619     p = stats.exponpow.logpdf(0, 1)
8620     assert_equal(p, 0.0)
8621 
8622     # Check pdf and logpdf at x = 0 for other values of b.
8623     p = stats.exponpow.pdf(0, [0.25, 1.0, 1.5])
8624     assert_equal(p, [np.inf, 1.0, 0.0])
8625     p = stats.exponpow.logpdf(0, [0.25, 1.0, 1.5])
8626     assert_equal(p, [np.inf, 0.0, -np.inf])
8627

8629 def test_gengamma_edge():
8630     # Regression test for gh-3985.
8631     p = stats.gengamma.pdf(0, 1, 1)
8632     assert_equal(p, 1.0)
8633 
8634 
8635 @pytest.mark.parametrize("a, c, ref, tol",
8636                          [(1500000.0, 1, 8.529426144018633, 1e-15),
8637                           (1e+30, 1, 35.95771492811536, 1e-15),
8638                           (1e+100, 1, 116.54819318290696, 1e-15),
8639                           (3e3, 1, 5.422011196659015, 1e-13),
8640                           (3e6, -1e100, -236.29663213396054, 1e-15),
8641                           (3e60, 1e-100, 1.3925371786831085e+102, 1e-15)])
8642 def test_gengamma_extreme_entropy(a, c, ref, tol):
8643     # The reference values were calculated with mpmath:
8644     # from mpmath import mp
8645     # mp.dps = 500
8646     #
8647     # def gen_entropy(a, c):
8648     #     a, c = mp.mpf(a), mp.mpf(c)
8649     #     val = mp.digamma(a)
8650     #     h = (a * (mp.one - val) + val/c + mp.loggamma(a) - mp.log(abs(c)))
8651     #     return float(h)
8652     assert_allclose(stats.gengamma.entropy(a, c), ref, rtol=tol)
8653 
8654 
8655 def test_gengamma_endpoint_with_neg_c():
8656     p = stats.gengamma.pdf(0, 1, -1)
8657     assert p == 0.0
8658     logp = stats.gengamma.logpdf(0, 1, -1)
8659     assert logp == -np.inf
8660

8665     assert_almost_equal(p, 1./199/198)
8666 
8667     p = stats.gengamma._munp(-2, 10, 1.)
8668     assert_almost_equal(p, 1./9/8)

8671 def test_ksone_fit_freeze():
8672     # Regression test for ticket #1638.
8673     d = np.array(
8674         [-0.18879233, 0.15734249, 0.18695107, 0.27908787, -0.248649,
8675          -0.2171497, 0.12233512, 0.15126419, 0.03119282, 0.4365294,
8676          0.08930393, -0.23509903, 0.28231224, -0.09974875, -0.25196048,
8677          0.11102028, 0.1427649, 0.10176452, 0.18754054, 0.25826724,
8678          0.05988819, 0.0531668, 0.21906056, 0.32106729, 0.2117662,
8679          0.10886442, 0.09375789, 0.24583286, -0.22968366, -0.07842391,
8680          -0.31195432, -0.21271196, 0.1114243, -0.13293002, 0.01331725,
8681          -0.04330977, -0.09485776, -0.28434547, 0.22245721, -0.18518199,
8682          -0.10943985, -0.35243174, 0.06897665, -0.03553363, -0.0701746,
8683          -0.06037974, 0.37670779, -0.21684405])
8684 
8685     with np.errstate(invalid='ignore'):
8686         with suppress_warnings() as sup:
8687             sup.filter(IntegrationWarning,
8688                        "The maximum number of subdivisions .50. has been "
8689                        "achieved.")
8690             sup.filter(RuntimeWarning,
8691                        "floating point number truncated to an integer")
8692             stats.ksone.fit(d)

8694 
8695 def test_norm_logcdf():
8696     # Test precision of the logcdf of the normal distribution.
8697     # This precision was enhanced in ticket 1614.
8698     x = -np.asarray(list(range(0, 120, 4)))
8699     # Values from R
8700     expected = [-0.69314718, -10.36010149, -35.01343716, -75.41067300,
8701                 -131.69539607, -203.91715537, -292.09872100, -396.25241451,
8702                 -516.38564863, -652.50322759, -804.60844201, -972.70364403,
8703                 -1156.79057310, -1356.87055173, -1572.94460885, -1805.01356068,
8704                 -2053.07806561, -2317.13866238, -2597.19579746, -2893.24984493,
8705                 -3205.30112136, -3533.34989701, -3877.39640444, -4237.44084522,
8706                 -4613.48339520, -5005.52420869, -5413.56342187, -5837.60115548,
8707                 -6277.63751711, -6733.67260303]
8708 
8709     assert_allclose(stats.norm().logcdf(x), expected, atol=1e-8)
8710 
8711     # also test the complex-valued code path
8712     assert_allclose(stats.norm().logcdf(x + 1e-14j).real, expected, atol=1e-8)
8713 
8714     # test the accuracy: d(logcdf)/dx = pdf / cdf \equiv exp(logpdf - logcdf)
8715     deriv = (stats.norm.logcdf(x + 1e-10j)/1e-10).imag
8716     deriv_expected = np.exp(stats.norm.logpdf(x) - stats.norm.logcdf(x))
8717     assert_allclose(deriv, deriv_expected, atol=1e-10)
8718 
8719 
8720 def test_levy_l_sf():
8721     # Test levy_l.sf for small arguments.
8722     x = np.array([-0.016, -0.01, -0.005, -0.0015])
8723     # Expected values were calculated with mpmath.
8724     expected = np.array([2.6644463892359302e-15,
8725                          1.523970604832107e-23,
8726                          2.0884875837625492e-45,
8727                          5.302850374626878e-147])
8728     y = stats.levy_l.sf(x)
8729     assert_allclose(y, expected, rtol=1e-13)
8730 
8731 
8732 def test_levy_l_isf():
8733     # Test roundtrip sf(isf(p)), including a small input value.
8734     p = np.array([3.0e-15, 0.25, 0.99])
8735     x = stats.levy_l.isf(p)
8736     q = stats.levy_l.sf(x)
8737     assert_allclose(q, p, rtol=5e-14)
